In my opinion, I think Saints Row The Third is better than Saints Row IV.

reviewText:
Saints Row: The Third takes place three years after the previous game. You are the gangleader of the Third Street Saints. The Saints are no longer just a brutal and effective criminal operation but now a fully-fledged media empire with their time split equally between doing dirt and setting up legitimate businesses and a popular line of merchandising.
After a bank heist gone wrong, the Saints find themselves in Steelport, butting heads with a local crime group known as the Syndicate. From there it is the classic rise to power story.
The appearance and personality of the Saints' leader is completely up to you, thanks to the character editor. You can make him or her look genuinely cool, or a complete abomination. If you want to change your look, or even your sex, visit a plastic surgeon in the city and change it. If you want a new outfit, there are shops full of every type of fashion imaginable.
Missions place you in increasingly unpredictable situations. It starts out fairly low-key with a raid on a military base to steal weapons for the gang, but it finishes with an explosive finale involving tanks, jets and city-levelling explosions. In between, there is a zombie outbreak, a trip inside a Tron-like computer world and much more, it gets wilder and more varied.
There is also an element of choice to the decisions you make. Certain missions see you choosing between two options that will affect the story, sometimes in quite dramatic ways.
The game has a lot of replay value, after finishing the main story you are able to do a lot of side missions, e.g. car-stealing missions and assassinations.
The best way to play Saints Row: The Third is to play with a friend. The co-op action and the careful attention to detail in the co-op mechanics are masterful. It is easy to drop in and out of a friend‚Äôs game and the way progress is tracked is very smart. If you join a game where the other person is further along in the plot than you are, you can still play a plot mission with them.
The dialogue between the characters is consistently hilarious. The game is packed with in-jokes, meta humor and constantly swerves into almost surreal territory.
The graphics may not be mind blowing, instead the game really shines with the sound. Everything sounds great from the gun battles to the snippets of incidental speech that you get when wandering around. The voice acting takes it up a notch though with some truly memorable performances. The best thing is the music selection though. A great selection of dance, hip hop, indie and metal are on offer from the in-game radio stations.
Overall I think the game is fantastic. It just gives you so much to do and a lot of fun if you play with a friend. Saints Row: The Third is worth to buy.

Sounds 10/10
Graphics 7/10
Gameplay 8/10
Atmosphere 9/10

reviewText:
AT A GLANCE(Full review follows below)

Game Name: Saints Row: The Third
Original Release: 2011
Genre Tags: Sandbox; Action; Open-World; Comedy
My Overall Grade: A+
Estimated Playtime (Campaign): 15-40 hours
Multiplayer Aspect: Optional
Recommended To: Established fans of the genre; Those intrigued by the genre; Fans of the intellectual property; Sandbox gamers; Casual gamers
REVIEWSaints Row: The Third is a masterwork of a game, and a quintessential specimen of its genre. There is a perfect balance of pragmatism and ludicrousness inherent to each and every aspect of the game. The mosaic of realistic and ridiculous themes is expertly crafted into one of the most enjoyable games in existence, let alone in the sandbox genre. All but the most extremely discerning gamers should be able to enjoy it.

One of the first features of Saints Row: The Third that will jump out at you is the fact it is full of preposterous themes, demonstrated not only in the narrative and atmospheric elements, but also the gameplay itself. And so, you definitely aren't supposed to approach this game seriously. That becomes painfully obvious once you learn that you can hop out of a speeding jet and crash face first into the middle of a city with no parachute... only to bounce up and run down the street naked, caving in people's skulls with giant purple sex toys.

Yet despite being a heavy-handed and purposeful parody of itself, the narrative of the game is actually entertaining and logically sensible (by that I mean it adheres to the logic of the gameworld, not real life). And the ludicrousness doesn‚Äôt ever get so totally out of hand that it starts to feel like a ‚Äùsimulator‚Äù game; there is always some semblance of a purpose and direction. Saints Row: The Third is a good example of how a game doesn‚Äôt have to be serious, but also can have an entertaining and somewhat logical narrative.

There is also a number of factors which add a significant layer of customization, progression, and statistics to the game‚Äî all of which contribute to increasing the overall epicness of the experience. For one, there is a wide range of customizing ability, from your character to your vehicles. Many hours can be spent just changing the theme of your gang. There is also a system of XP and level progression, which is uncommon in the genre, but synthesizes perfectly in Saints Row: The Third. You can use your level-ups to customize certain abilities of your character, and if you devote enough time, you can eventually make yourself invincible purely through the level system (not cheats/codes).

Furthermore, the gameworld in Saints Row: The Third is a very enjoyable sandbox to play in, and there is a lot of potential for riotous fun to be had. The gameworld is large enough to be interesting, but not so large it becomes a burden to traverse. To keep you busy between campaign missions, there are dozens of side-missions of various gameplay styles which add pleasant diversity. Outside the primary and secondary missions, there are numerous minigames and challenges (stunting, base jumping, racing, streaking, etc.) which all contribute to creating an environment where you can spend hours of gameplay just messing around and having fun, without actively pursuing missions or progressing the game.

And another amazing feature of this game is the ability to play the actual campaign in co-op mode.  Instead of just messing around in the sandbox with friends, you can actually beat the game together.

There is also a lot of DLC, which ranges from cosmetic additions to full-blown extra campaigns. I would say it is definitely worth it to get the GOTY edition right from the start.

Follow my curation page to see more of my recommendations!

reviewText:
Saints Row: The Third. I thought it was a very good game. The thing that got me the most was the comical humor. The costumes and wardrobes, to the sexual references and balancing dead bodies with exaggerated weapon effects. I found this game to be a LOT beter compared to Saints Row and Saints Row II. If follows the time line, which is always a plus. The amount of things you can do, in my opinion, is much more and better than GTA. GTA is more on a serious note, which is good; Saints Row: The Third has some serious moments, but knows how to offer a laugh and good time with a balance.

The Story Line is pretty simple and basic, but not as generic as you would expect. You have a mixture of things, from saving your Homies, to fighting Gangs, Police, Military, Politicians, Zombies and Aliens. The gangs, especially one in particular are trying to take turf. What kind of gang isn't? The Genki line I found the most fun. It's basically like a game show arena. You fight your wat through enemies as well as the environments. It's definitely rewarding in the end, but not as much as it should be. In the end, you begin to gather forces for a take over. A bloody, deadly and annoying battle takes place.

The Combat System was very fun. Shooting duel pistols at enemies and watching them fly across the street. The Genki Mobile went shoots flames around all sides of the car as you drive, leaving a flaming inferno of destruction in your path. Falling from a disintergrating plane and shooting people as you fall with style. Fighting in wrestling rings with other gang members. Or you can do it with classic style by running them over with your cars and going on a shooting rampage. Some people may frown on it, but it is only a game after all. It could even relieve some frustrations.

Didn't have much of an Online Experience. It's pretty difficult to find others willing to play or willing to stay. So, unless you have a friend to play this with, I would recommend that more. At least if you want the achievements that go with this.

4/5 Singleplayer   2/5 Online/Coop

reviewText:
Take a moment to picture this scenario; you‚Äôre in a helicopter hovering above the roof a several-story tall penthouse that‚Äôs currently owned by a rival gang of yours. You then leap out, skydive downwards and release your parachute before finally landing and beating up everyone with a ten-feet long, pink ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•. And yet that‚Äôs only a sparse indication to just how ludicrous and over-the-top Saints Row 3 truly is. Of course, this should come as no surprise to anyone who played its precursors, but irrespective if you‚Äôre familiar with Saints Row‚Äôs crazy antics or not, the third iteration is unlike any other game this year ‚Äì and it‚Äôs playful tone and hysterical characters will have you in stitches.
Saints Row 3 still centers on a small gang of violent, yet eccentric criminals who go by the name ‚ÄúThe Saints‚Äù. But after a ridiculously crazy opening, the Saints find themselves in the troubled town of Steelport  and are poised to overthrow a notorious crime syndicate called, well, ‚ÄúThe Syndicate‚Äù. The premise is incredibly straightforward, but it‚Äôs the cast of characters and sublime dialogue that really makes Saints Row 3 so memorable. Riding shotgun with you throughout the game is a mash-up of crooks, gangsters, computer nerds and a pimp whose voice may or may not be auto-tuned. The story takes a while to get moving, but getting wrapped in Saints Row 3‚Äôs narrative is not mandatory in order to enjoy the game.
In case you absolutely haven‚Äôt heard or seen anything with the name Saints Row on it ‚Äî it‚Äôs a sandbox, open-world experience. You‚Äôre set loose in a madhouse of a city and free to tackle missions, side activities, cause some serious commotion or regain control over large chunks and city squares of Steelport. The game also features some fairly basic third-person shooter mechanics. There‚Äôs no cover system in place, but you can shoot up enemies with a massive selection of firearms and gadgets, perform dive rolls and rush in and take out enemies using hand-to-hand combat. Little has changed from Saints Row 2 in that regard, but the combat is still satisfying nonetheless.
Saints Row 3‚Äôs design is heavily focused on advancing your character and your supremacy over Steelport, since completing missions grants you money which you can spend on a huge selection of attributes and skill-boosting upgrades. Also, completing vital story missions unlocks ‚Äúcribs‚Äùwhere you can customize your load out and much else. This all feeds into the Reputation system, which allows you to level up and get access to more powerful abilities.
Another strong component of Saints Row 3 is the mission variety. While some objectives boil down to kill x, escort z or defend y, there are still some very enjoyable missions and set-pieces that punctuate important story moments. You‚Äôll get to infiltrate nuclear plants, man a good number of ground and aerial vehicles to carry out large-scale assaults, defend a freighter from incoming enemies and much more. The missions are mostly easy and feature a generous checkpoint system, and you can always take on a good number of side missions for extra cash and rep.
The AI of your friendly gang members ‚Äìaptly called ‚Äúhomies‚Äù‚Äì was one of the biggest complaints leveled towards Saints Row 2, and though it‚Äôs not perfect here, it‚Äôs still been improved significantly and gang members now drop enemies at a more consistent pace.
Adversaries on the other hand are about as inept and dumb as they can be; not running away from grenades or failing to respond as you fill them with lead. To make matters worse, you face an extremely small number of enemies ‚Äî there are standard goons, more armored ones, and gigantic, hulk-like enemies dubbed ‚ÄúBrutes‚Äù. As a result, the combat loses some its luster after a while, so the real variety comes from the vehicle or on-rails-sequences you‚Äôll infrequently take part in.
Saints Row 3 looks good for an open-world title, with excellent animations and colorful explosions ‚Äì which is a good thing since you‚Äôll be seeing tons and tons of explosions ‚Äì and the game also has one of the deepest character customization editors I‚Äôve seen all year, and your custom appearance is reflected to a hundred-percent in the cut scenes. The game also scales itself well to lower-end machines, and features support from Direct X9 to Direct X11.
The world, however, still looks slightly dull here and there, and the physics are often sporadic and glitchy from time to time. Load times also come in a large abundance and on the whole, Saints Row 3 is pretty, but still has a few too many rough edges.
With excellent writing, strong variety, lots of stuff to do and an incredibly fun and endearing attitude, Saints Row 3 is one of the most quirky games to come out in 2011. The combat could still be deeper and the AI is still noticeably weak and coupled with some technical deficiencies and a disappointing extra mode, Saints Row 3 strictly settles for being great, but it that‚Äôs more than enough to warrant a recommendation.

reviewText:
Some sandbox games are well respected for their realism. After all, it takes a lot to create a city, populate it, give players a chance to live in a virtual parody of reality, and at the same time do so in a way that draws players in an makes them feel they truly are in an enclosed living breathing world. Well grounded characters have to blend together with a physics engine that makes sense, because players are always going to be searching for that one thing that feels too inconsistent with what we know about the world today. So it's fairly impressive how well Saints Row: The Third draws in players considering that every ounce of realism is tossed right out the door within the first ten minutes, giving players an amazingly wild ride that features some of the most memorable (and believable) characters you'll ever have the pleasure of playing with in a sandbox game.

Don't get fooled by the fact that this is the third game in the series; even though the plot picks off right where the other games left off players are treated to a nice summary of the Saints' accomplishments prior to this installment. Having reached the height of their fame and popularity the local gang has become a bit full of themselves. They're now robbing banks with masks that look like their faces, cutting movie deals, and just generally getting used to the good life. This complacency eventually gets them into quite a bit of trouble, and soon the Saints find themselves in a new, unfamiliar city having to work their way back from the ground up.

Apart from the main story being a little predictable, it's a fantastic ride through and through. Part of this has to do with how over-the-top the action is in just about every situation. Stealing UAV bombing drones, skydiving from helicopters to crash parties and freefalling from an airplane while shooting through falling debris to kill rival gang members in mid air. These all set the tone at an early point in the game that the action is going to be consistently over the top and the player will get the experience all the best parts of it. With the mind already suspending a lot of belief that any of these things could ever happen it's easy to believe that the storyline is just background fluff for the experience, but the character interactions are so genuine that it's hard not to really feel for the Saints' cause.

There's absolutely no time wasted in any of the dialogue, no fillers with useless information, no string of swearing just for the need to be edgy, and in a world where players can dress up like vampire hookers driving a ice cream truck, while avoiding mutant hulks that throw people at you, being able to be to really connect with these characters so effortlessly is incredibly valuable.

But thankfully the character design isn't the only solid thing in Saints Row: The Third. Combat naturally plays a large role in attempting to carve out a gang empire and that's exactly where the game becomes additively satisfying. Guns are just about everywhere and take up the usual role in any third person shooter. There are sniper rifles, rocket launchers, pistols, machine guns, and all of them are simple as pointing and clicking away. Then, of course, you have weapons like the laser guided precision airstrike gun that summons up sharks, or mind-controlling squid gun (which naturally shoots out a squid which takes over any potentially hostile NPC). The sheer wackiness of some of the weapons that players get access to is both shocking and hilarious, and it's clear that only some sort of genius could ever come up with the vast array of weaponry featured in this game.

Melee weapons offer a little bit more versatility this time around, as some attacks can be used indefinitely, while others have limited use but offer special attacks like an explosive knockback. Melee itself plays another huge role in the game, and is arguably the most defining feature of the franchise.

Fluid, over the top, and a lot of fun, melee moves mix up the typical shooting elements of the game to great effect. Drop kicking one enemy only to run over and take another as a hostage, all without changing weapons or being forced to handle different mechanics, makes tackling a large group of foes very easy. This is good, because players only ever seem to fight a small horde enemies every time.

Naturally with weapons, cars, and gangsters come customization features, of which Saints Row 3 isn't remotely short of. Players are able to level up weapons, increasing both individual features and aesthetic looks over time. Vehicles on the other hand have just as many customization options as the player character does, and all of it is incredibly easy to control. Grabbing a car and tossing on a unique paint job is incredibly easy, and using cash earned in-game you can choose to tweak the frame of individual vehicles with little to no effort. Even those who are typically disinterested in visually tweaking cars should find that the quick and painless options offered make the process fairly fun.

Character customization on the other hand is a completely different beast altogether. Outside of editing a characters general face, height, gender, voice and all the other usual suspects players are allowed to dress their characters to an amazing extent. Visiting clothing stores throughout the city will grant players the option of shopping from that particular style and anything from business attire, street clothing, bondage gear, or just plain strange costumes. The selection is fairly large, made better only by the fact that players will generally find these stores by bumping into them mid-exploration rather than simply searching them out by necessity.

Another fantastic point of customization in Saints Row: The Third is how players are allowed to manage their in-game finances, with an offering of more than just customized weapons and crazy looking hats. Players can also purchase property all over the city that generates revenue every hour, or serves as alternative safe houses where players can store vehicles, weapons, or clothing. It's one of many different rewards for exploration that doesn't come in the form of finding hidden items.

Graphically there's not too much to be dissatisfied with when it comes to Saints Row: The Third, as it's an open world title that does everything it can to absolutely minimize any loading times. Naturally entering a special vehicle segments or a special indoor building will trigger a bit of loading, but for the most part players should find the entire experience relatively seamless. The soundtrack is also well done, being a great blend of scripted talk show radio work, satirical commercials, and real music. Special missions will often come along with a predetermined soundtrack, which sets the tone fairly well as long as you're in the mood to Kanye West or some other rap/rock artist.

Saints Row: The Third is, simply put, absolutely insanity at its best. While some sandbox titles strive for realism, or destructive scale, Saints Row: The Third instead takes a combination of all the features that have defined sandbox games as of late (driving, shooting, wandering large setpiece cities) alongside a blend of everything that defines how memorably wacky a game can be. There's very little in this title that wont satisfy most gamers, and that the entire game can be run through with co-op just adds to the fun. Getting every property, finding each hidden item, wiping out every gang and finishing every mission will naturally take a bit of time but the best part about Saints Row: The Third isn't about the hours you intentionally invest, it's finding out how much time you've lost having fun without ever realizing it.

http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=383235866

Highly Recommended

Crazy and non-sense open-world game, really funny in what it does. At first I thought it was just a GTA clone, but it has its reasons to exist.
It has tons of stuff to do, with surprisingly enough variety, and basically rewards you for everything; a little bit on the easy side, but this doesn't make messing around less fun.

Co-op is surely the best thing this open-world has to offer, being it pratically the same game with another player, also, it's really easy to jump in.

Reccomended if you want to have fun in a mad open-world game, preferably with a friend.

reviewText:
Affable & liberating // Recommended for over-the-top thrillseekers
+ Hilarious dialogue & general sense of humor
+ Clear objective markers and GPS directions; you're almost guaranteed to never get lost
+ Fantastic soundtrack; covering all major genres from screamo metal to hip-hop, the game boasts quality entries for each
+ Decently large, open-world gameplay
+ Story is absolutley, incredibly ridiculous in the best possible way
+ Doesn't take itself seriously as a game; focuses on fun and replayability
+ Missions deviate satisfyingly in gameplay; there is a wide variety of activities, from hijacking vehicles while in a helicopter, to jumping in front of moving vehicles to rack up insurance money
+ Massive variety in character, weapon, and gang customization
+ Visuals are adequate and stand up fairly well to today's standards
+ All dialogue is competently voice-acted
+ Side mission activities are a blast to participate in, and enjoy a healthy variance
+ Fun and easy to mod

- Fire zombies bug; in one mission where the player must fight a zombie infestation, often zombies will swarm the player and (none of the zombies being on fire) will set you on fire, resulting in a continuous replay of the 'I'm on fire!' animation (extremely aggravating)
- AI for allies tends to behave poorly; your 'homies' will often walk out into heavy fire, forcing you to run out and help them (which is timed)

If you enjoyed this review, please follow my curator page. Feel free to join my group, LockeProposal's Big Day Out for discussion and announcements, and I also have a budding YouTube Channel for those interested. Thanks for reading!

reviewText: Saints Row: The Third is an over the top, open world over the shoulder third person shooter with strong action, good controls and some over sexualized comedy. There are plenty of giant purple bats, leather clad dancers, and awkward situations all done for the sake of comedy. You play as the head of a gang from the start, but really its a group of three tight friends that grows bigger to include a giant powerhouse, an ex FBI tech geek, a pretensions actor, a serious turncoat twin and an auto tuned pimp. These aren't just quest givers, you can call on them to help you on missions. When they're with you, they're smart enough to find cover in gun fights, take hostages and even steal a car to follow you when you drive off without them. When your homies" fall

reviewText:
After successfully taking over the town of Stillwater in the last game, the Saints popularity and brand has exploded. Billboards are everywhere, they have their own energy drink, and people stop them in the street for autographs even in the midst of battle.

But it's not easy being at the top, it just makes you a bigger target. During the first mission, a bank heist goes wrong, and you find yourself fighting rival gangs and a military force in a brand new city - Steelport. This is an industrial city with big skyscrapers, factories... and maniacs with rocket launchers.

When you first bring up that world map, the art design and music instantly makes you think of Grand Theft Auto IV's map. But Saints Row isn't a realistic gritty sandbox where you pay bridge tolls and go bowling... it's more of an absurdest parody of the GTA games.

One of the biggest differences between the two franchises, is that here you get to live out your wildest character customisation dreams - which we'll always appreciate. There's an almost endless supply of facial tweaks, from eyelids to reptilian make-up... there's stacks of gestures and taunts... skinny and fat sliders, skin colours that include metallic yellow and green... and even a 'sex appeal' slider. There are also a stack of voices to choose from for your character. Most of our favourite voices are back from Saints Row 2, with one notable addition - the zombie.

It's quite an achievement that all of these clothes fit so well, with no clipping on all body types I tried. And there's something about seeing these crazy characters in cut scenes that not only makes this a very individual experience - but it just makes the main character seem even more insane then he/she already is. It also surprised me how well made these cut-scenes are, for a game that embraces the silly so much. The whole presentation is well done actually, and the selection of music on the radio stations is great too... but it's the mission music that really compliments the action perfectly.

The intro to this game is so exciting. In the first hour you'll rip a vault out of a bank, get kidnapped, parachute out of a plane, then shoot the window out of one coming towards you, take out everyone in it and then fight goons in mid air until you land in Steelport. They put a lot of work into those first couple of missions... and straight away you realise that everything looks better compared to the last game. There's a floppy, cartoony feel to the world and the character models; which you especially notice riding the sidewalk. All the models look more solid, with better animations in general. The cars look better too, with improved physics which makes for some excellent crashes.

Once you zoom around, you'll notice how smooth the world is. It's not beautiful but there's a lot on screen at once and there's a good draw distance, with a nice amount of detail. One thing that always bugged in me SR2 is the way vehicles would spawn and disappear as you looked left and right, which broke the world a bit for me. I noticed that they've fixed that.

Getting in and out of cars is something that you do a LOT in a game like this, and here in Saints Row 3 you actually have a 'quick hijack' which lets you leap into vehicles instantly; and that sums up the overall concept of this game - which is that it doesn't want to waste your time, and tries to keep things as fun and fast as possible. There's even a 'warp to shore' mechanic so you don't waste time swimming. Developer Volition really does a good job of keeping the gameplay streamlined.

Enemy AI is a bit hit and miss though, sometimes they won't notice you for a while, or they'll just stand out in the open. There's no cover system so their options are a bit limited anyway. And in most of the missions where you're fighting a bunch of goons, there are usually only 2 or 3 character types, which can't help but feel out of place for a game with such great customisation to your own character.

The story missions in Saints Row: The Third are full of variety. The best range from exciting base infiltrations, ambushes, jet missions and some other crazy stuff that I won't spoil for you. There's no longer any multiplayer VS which I don't think will be missed that much to be honest.. But now there is a wave mode.. called '‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•D MODE' where you'll face off against a variety of foes that grow in size, and shrink... in a bunch of situations. It's horribly unbalanced but undeniably fun.

Now, this is a very crude game, and I have to say I've really wrestled with my morals on this one, and what I consider to be passably appropriate in a game like this. On one hand - I get the same maniacal joy of being an idiot, running people over and enjoying all of that that silly humour the same as anyone else. And I also get that this is a particular genre that is about crossing the line - while not taking itself too seriously... However, I can't help but ask myself what kind of a person is okay with grabbing a woman by the hair and face-slamming them into the pavement. It is pretty full on that you can do these special moves on the civilians - I was okay with doing it to the enemies, they're trying to kill you. There isn't much punishment either for hurting the civilians - cops come but you don't feel much of a penalty.

I felt with GTA IV it was treated as a real crime, and here it's just glorified with those special moves. Should that choice even be there, and does it need to be? Do I really need to wield giant purple ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• - why is that in the game?

One bit that took it too far was the human trafficking mission... you open a bunch of crates looking for 'hoes' to which you can then keep as your own hoes for long term income, or sell back for a quick cash reward. On the boat where they're kept, you'll find all sorts of contraptions such as 'fisting machines'... and that crossed the line.

I'm so torn with this one, I almost feel hypocritical because some parts I was absolutely fine with, but other parts I just found abhorrent. I don't want be a prude, but the sexual and degrading elements of the game took it way too far and put a dampener on my experience. I mean, what's next? Violence against children? Would that be okay in a game like this, because it's not meant to be taken seriously so it just gets a free pass?

All in all it's a very good game, good graphics, good story and good missions. This is a game that should definitely be played by adults. If you can look past those few tasteless elements that just go too far, it's still worth an 9/10.

reviewText:
Okay, after playing this for 6.7 hours.. I had to write a review about this game.

Saints Row 3 (The Third) is essentialy one of the best games I've ever played in my entire life.

The cons and pros will be listed below.

Pros:

- Has a well-balanced story that isn't too childish and goofy or too serious

- Has a amazing customization system which let's you have almost any look you've probably dreamed about in your life for a character or for a vehicle. (Seriously, if APB Reloaded's customization system had a son.. it'd be this game's one.)

- You can punch people with a large purple d*ldo on a stick.

- The character can have 4+ diferent voices (and some can be a female voice, even if your character is a male.)

- There are over 25 taunts to choose from (all of them are adapted to your character's voice)

- The co-op is smooth and ISN'T BROKEN (Yes. I'm looking at you, GTA 4.)

- You can complete the story-mode missions with your friend in co-op.

- You can run over people's cars with a colour-customized tank (and the cars are only crashed on the spot you ran them over. It looks realistic.)

- You can revive your teammates or your friend countless times within 25-30 seconds after their health has run out.

- The missions are EPIC.

- There is a wide modding community.

Cons:

-I couldn't find any neko ears on the clothes stores, but I'm sure I can install a mod and get some.


My final veredict is a 9.9/10, buy this, NAOW. YOU NEED IT. (With all of the DLCs if possible, they are totally worth it.)

P.S: Don't shoot Professor Genki, he'll beat the ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• out of you.

reviewText:
Saints Row: The Third - ReviewSaints Row: The Third is a third person shooter taking place in the open world city of Steelport. It's a game that doesn't really take itself too seriously which is either a good or bad thing for some and the graphics are cartoonish to go along with the humor of the game which might fall flat for some people at times.

In Steelport you'll be spending your time either completing the missions, doing activities and finding the collectables, or going around the city causing mayhem. The story itself is based around getting revenge for someone and thats about it, lasting roughly 10+ hours. To make it even worse; Saints Row 4 basically renders every action you did during this game entirely pointless. However the missions themselves are pretty enjoyable, and the interactions between the characters are interesting despite not being too fleshed out.

While the story isn't too particularily compelling and the game's humor and graphics may not appeal to everyone, Saints Row: The Third is solid overall and pretty fun to play by yourself or with a friend. It occassionally goes on sale for $3.74 and it's definitely worth purchasing for that amount.

Pros:‚ñ∫ Fun single player and co-op gameplay experience
‚ñ∫ Lots of customization options for your character, gang members and cars
‚ñ∫ Variety of missions
‚ñ∫ Interesting characters
‚ñ∫ Many Activities to do and secrets to find
‚ñ∫ Upgrade system (guns, character, homies)
‚ñ∫ The timing for the songs / tracks bring out the feeling of a scene, especially the final mission
‚ñ∫ Solid controls

Cons:‚ñ∫ Linear progression in the plot, where as the first two games would let you choose the order you could take out the gangs
‚ñ∫ Story isn't particularily interesting or compelling
‚ñ∫ Acheivement hunters won't be able to 100% due to the character gallary being down
‚ñ∫ No cutscene replay option as with the first two games
‚ñ∫ The city itself is particularily dull and lifeless
‚ñ∫ Stuck with any upgrades choices you make, can't switch them on or off

Hit / Miss:‚ñ∫ Humor is a hit or miss for some people
‚ñ∫ Few one time only choices that affect bonuses you'll recieve, but otherwise won't affect the storyline
‚ñ∫ Upgrading too much may ruin your experience if you want a challenge

Personal Rating:Avoid at all costs
Pick up during a sale
Worth Playing
Must Play

reviewText:
It‚Äôs that time of the year again, with the Deep Silver
Publisher Weekend Sale and your lovely dark rose
Summer-Rain is scrolling through the sales catalog
on Steam. She calls you from her room, asking what
you know of the Saints Row series, because she‚Äôs
thinking of buying the Metro bundle for her fix of
post-apocalyptic gameplay.

Peeking into her lair of lilac walls and sullen grey
furniture, she looks at you with a slight tilt to her
head which makes her look all the cuter than she
already is. You look upwards in thought before
grinning. ‚ÄúI know the Metro bundle is tempting‚Ä¶
but if you haven‚Äôt heard of Saints Row‚Ä¶ they, uh‚Ä¶
have‚Ä¶ ‚Äòwomen‚Äôs devices of pleasure‚Äô as weapons.‚Äù

Summer-Rain looked bored waiting for your response,
but her eyes widened to the point she where looks
absolutely livid. Suddenly her eyes narrow and her lips
curve into a thin smile before asking you whether
you already have the game. You nod, and Summer-Rain
purchases Saints Row: The Third and Saints Row IV.

‚ÄúThose‚Äôre all I need, right? You sure I don‚Äôt need to
play the first Saints Row or Saints Row 2?‚Äù You shake
your head as you drape your hoodie across her
shoulders and nuzzle her nape for a bit, explaining that
Saints Row: The Third has such clean storytelling, simple
gameplay and so much in-your-face action that she‚Äôll
hurt from the sheer awesome of it all.

She looks like a child now, as Summer-Rain looks up at
you, eyes full of wonder by the description of the game.
You look back at her and assure her that she won‚Äôt
regret it, and that there‚Äôs another thing she likes: co-op!
She orders you to get on your computer next door, so
that the both of you can start playing together.

So she‚Äôs installed Saints Row: The Third and now both of
you are freefalling in the air when a rival gang; the
Morningstars, who want to muscle in on your gang;
the Saints‚Äô, who are holding the title of World‚Äôs Greatest
Gang comes to a head after a battle in the Morningstars‚Äô
luxury airliner.

You and Summer-Rain rebuild the Saints from the very
bottom to the highest of skyscrapers in an unknown city
to the Saints; Steelport. Together, you and Summer-Rain
show the rival Morningstars who‚Äôs the boss in a multitude
of crashing their gangland operations, buying property,
trying on new clothes for your player avatars and
shopping for the best gun upgrades with her by your side.

When the going got tough, you and Summer-Rain visited
the closest auto shop and modified the latest car both of
you stole and tear up the town, fighting the Morningstars‚Äô
two other gang partners, the tech-savvy, Daft Punk
lookalikes known as the Deckers and the brutish,
Mexican-wrestling-inspired Luchadores.

Your objective to conquer the City of Steelport does not
go unnoticed however, and the US Government sends in
a special anti-gang paramilitary force known as S.T.A.G.;
A group which takes a page from Halo and Marvel‚Äôs
S.H.I.E.L.D. with the level of technology they possess
and how far they will go to destroy all gang activity for
the good of the Ol‚Äô US of A.

After a time, Summer-Rain enters your door dressed in
purple and black, chewing bubblegum and sporting a
bob cut just like her player character in your co-op
game. You raise your eyebrow before she sits on top
of your lap, blocking the screen. You try to talk, but
she hushes you with her finger to your lips.

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs a school night‚Ä¶ time for us to sleep.‚Äù You protest,
pointing out that she was having as much fun as you
were, and that Steelport is almost under Saints control.

Summer-Rain pouts, leaving the room momentarily
before she enters again and brandishes a ‚Äòwoman‚Äôs
device of pleasure‚Äô, that looks like it was stolen from
Saints Row: The Third itself. Summer-Rain gives you
a threatening smirk while flopping her weapon about.

‚ÄúFun is fun, love‚Ä¶ but don‚Äôt finish the game in one
day! We have Saints Row IV to play and go through
together. Bed. Now!‚Äù

You dive under your bed and produce your own
‚Äòwoman‚Äôs pleasure device‚Äô and run after her,
uttering a battle cry as she playfully screams back
into her room in tow.

By the next morning, everyone in class is wondering
why both you and Summer-Rain have purple bruises
and love bites after the end of the Deep Silver
Publisher Weekend Sale.

‚ÄòWomen‚Äôs devices of pleasure‚Äô as weapons.

Because steam would have censored the word d**do.

Saints Row.

The Third.

reviewText: This game remind me old GTA San Andreas a lot and I loved that freedom of big open world, where you can run around in order to fight with other gangs, police or special units. Game allows you to customize your character and even more, your gang and vehicles, with wide variety of options. Storyline and quests are not so interesting or important although its kind of funny main objectives are just to get somewhere and destroy evething that stands in your way, but there are many more tasks which helps you control city territories like escort, gang operations and so on, these are really funny and interesting. The best thing in whole game (at least for me) were Professor Genki's Super Ethical Reality Climax missions where your focus is to survive, fulfill money limit by killing mascots or evading traps and get to the end of arena. Only thing I would refer to in negative way is that you can get everything from the beginning easily, load of money, best cars or even planes of helicopter, almost every weapon, on the other side I appreciated earning respect and unlocking new options with it and thats where I spent that loads of money.\n\n8/10

reviewText: When the GTA series started becoming more serious, the Saints Row series chose to appease the other half of us by becoming more ridiculous and over the top.  Saints Row the Third is as whacky, immature and over the top as it gets, giving you absurdly powerful rewards in a short time, loads of upgradeable weapons, tons of car mod opportunities and an un-hindered tag along co-op mode, allowing for even higher levels of hilarity with a friend.  The story however may feel disjointed and lack context at times, plus, some will find their rewards less special because they get so many so quickly.  That isn't always bad however, because some of us just want to start going nuts as quick as possible, taking to the streets with a friend and delivering an underhanded rocket launcher swing to the groin of a man wearing a mascot costume.  This game is not for the easily offended or those who like a slow boil, but it welcomes those like myself who was bored by GTA4's lack of sandbox wonder.

reviewText:
The third time is more of a tease than a charm. Saints was going through that awkward stage of growing up and trying to find itself with this entry. Prior releases were closer to cheesy Grand Theft Auto clones with a little bit of wacky stuff thrown in (hitman missions found you murdering people in hotdog suits so that you could unlock a platinum weapon). The Third really tried to position itself as over top and zany, but it does not quite hit the mark.

Everything about the game, from mechanics on up, is fine. The guns shoot, the cars drive, and so on. But nothing quite ever gets over the top. The weapons are all a generic bunch (some shotguns, pistols, and so on) with the craziest set of weapons relying on a cool down rather than ammo. Yes there is a shark gun (which acts like an instant kill with a slow cool down, so you might as well use your shotgun) which is rather tame, or the mollusk launcher that actually stands out. Even at their most upgraded most of the guns felt the same and I couldn't be bothered to decide between generic rifle 1 or 2 because they both did an ok job at killing enemies, which are another problem.

Enemies, whether they are dressed like luchadores or cyber punk fans, are all pretty much the same. The most elite members will differ in their special weapons (a grenade launcher or a shock hammer respectively for example), but they both die quickly from bullets, like everyone else in the game. There is no need to switch up using your favorite gun to fight one gang or type of enemy from another. If I recall correctly, the brute enemy type is the one exception to this. The sameness of enemies is a pretty large problem because nearly every mission is you shooting waves of enemies, going to another area, and shooting some more while bits of dialogue drabble on. Simplicity is fine, not all games need variety, but if a game only has one trick it needs to pull that on trick off well. It becomes apparent pretty quick that the enemies and the weapons are, for the most part, just coats of paint. The other biggest part of missions and the game, is the getting there" part.

In a game with a hovercraft
date: you should not always be choosing the hovercraft just because it is the most convenient option. This is a problem for most open world games though: traveling around is not always fun. Grand Theft Auto San Andreas figured this out pretty quick with the "trip skip" feature that allowed you to retry missions fairly quickly. However
recommended: The Third has you selecting a mission

reviewText:
I completed this game after playing Saints Row IV 100% done and also i played this game with no DLC's but anyways review goes like this:

+ Good enough story but more important, it was very funny story with optional mission ending choices
+ Interesting characters with good voice acting
+ Lots of gameplay variety in story missions and side activities
+ Large character customization
+ Car tuning, character updates, clothes and properties to buy
+ Lot of easter eggs!
+ Graphics are good looking
+ In general, lot of stuff to do all around the city

- Below decent and very confusing driving system
- Sound-design is horrible, game sounds are bad quality and sounds cut off in some things too early or too late
- in late game you start getting money very easily with no effort and you can buy all things easily
- For experienced players even hard difficulty seems to be easy to play
- City where you play is little rip-off of Grand Theft Auto IV and seems to be very average to play in
- Cops and gangs are sometimes unfairly annoying when doing things around the city

Overall very good game and worth to play! I fairly recommend to play this game.

reviewText: Saints Row: The Third was actually my first introduction to the Saints Row series. It reminds me of a mixture of Grand Theft Auto: San Andreas meets Rambo, with all the shooting, guns, explosions, and the body count you leave in your wake. I've heard negative things about the game over the years, which is why I avoided trying it, and now I regret that decision. Saints Row: The Third is non-stop action. From the opening scenes where you are committing a robbery gone haywire, to jumping out of a plane without a parachute and performing stunts that rival those seen from hollywood, this game is a lot of fun. Basically, you start off after choosing or creating your own character, as the leader of the Saints, a once prestigous gang, who now has no money, and no respect. Slowly you must work to turn around your fortunes and build a criminal empire.\n\nWhile I did enjoy Saints Row: The Third, even on hardcore the game seemed a little to easy. Visually, it doesn't look bad for a game thats been out a few years now. The action scenes, were pretty good, immersive, and fun to both watch and play through. All in all it's a pretty good game.

Look this is Saints Row we're talking about here, if you don't know by now that its a fantastic game well... guess that explains why you're reading the reviews. So, as a quick TLDR Buy it, if you have more than enough money buy it and buy one for a friend, if you have enough money buy it, if you don't have enough money wait for it to go on sale, it always does.

Now for why you need to buy it right now.
Pre-Note: Saints row 4 is out so I don't get why you aren't looking at that but hey, whatever this game is just as good but less... super-hero-ey

Reason #1 : The game is Open world

Reason #2 : The game is like GTA where you can shoot some people have some fun, do whatever you want.

Reason #3 : The game has a very good Character Creation system so you can play as you want. Want to be a prom queen in high heels killing swat? sure. Wanna be a morbidly obese man in a thong and high heels? sure. Want to be high heels? Not possible, but you can be a toilet and some other... models...

Reason #4 : The game not taken seriously. if you want to play it serious the story is kind of.... off of real life standards but honestly its comedy gold. why would you play a realistic game?

reviewText:
Best words to describe Saints Row: The Third? Zany, outlandish and loony. Saints Row: The Third, the game that defined the series as what it is today.

Being one of my all-time favorite games, I will always recommend this for its sheer madness - Fall in love with the various personas you will meet throughout this game (or if you already played SR1/SR2, then rekindle your love for them!), all the while you're blowing up parts of the town of Steelport.

And in the midst of fighting the syndicates of Steelport to take control, you can always take a break and do some of the fun activities throughout the city (my favorites will always be the Genki ones, be sure to check the DLC as well).

And if things start seeming slow? Ask a friend to join you and cause havoc together, while dressed up as anything between Steampunk heroes to furries in animal suits to straight up thugs - Your street gang, your rules.

reviewText: There is no feeling like being a Saint in Steelport. Blowing up cars while driving, shooting people with rockets with no clothes on you, taking over a city in the gang banging way while the army hunts you down, this game is quite an experience. The characters are kind of stereotypical, but that only adds to the fun. The character customization is the richest one you'll ever see in a game; you can set your gender, race, build, facial features, body features, age, personality and more. While it may seem too ridiculous to pulverize people by hitting them with a giant purple ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•, after a while it will get to you and you'll enjoy those kind of things. The bad part is that it takes a while to get into it, since you can't enjoy the full madness from the beginning  and the story also gets more interesting later(like when the bridge gets fired down by a thousand rockets). This game can give you a fun time, provided that the exageration is not too much for you. I give this game an 8.7

reviewText:
http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=536029561

Before the credits roll you'll catsit a tiger, play a hilarious text adventure, get a sex change, hack up Mexican wrestlers with a chainsaw, visit a Tron-like computer world, and participate in many other ridiculous leisure activities. Saints Row the Third can be accused of being many things, but repetitive isn't one of them.

Some games create atmospheric worlds that attempt to draw you in with moving stories about characters seeking a second chance, or cast you as troubled superheroes who push themselves to the limit to fight evil. Saints Row: The Third is not like those games. Rather, it's the kind of game that gives you weapons called apocafists with which you can punch people, instantly making them explode in a bloody mess. The Third won't impress you with knockout visuals, move you with an absorbing story, or engage you with challenging combat. What it does, better than just about any game before, is embrace the idea of an open world as a place for play, constantly giving you access to awesome new toys and providing you with no shortage of exciting opportunities to use them.

One thing you definitely shouldn't ignore is the main story. Within just the first few missions, you plummet out of a plane and into an airborne shoot-out, skydive into a penthouse that belongs to a rival gang, use a UAV drone to call in guided missiles on tanks, and more. The missions eventually become a bit predictable for a while, serving as introductions to the other activities and diversions available to you in Steelport. But before long, they get wild again, packing in numerous surprises before culminating in one of two outrageous final missions.

Saints Row: The Third is buoyed to great heights by terrific mission design and by the remarkable assortment of vehicles and weapons it gives you with which to take over Steelport. Whether you're buying up property to increase your hourly income, cruising the city in your favorite vehicle to collect photo ops, drug packages, and sex dolls, or punching people to bits with those crazy apocafists, there's rarely a dull moment. Saints Row: The Third succeeds tremendously at delivering its unique brand of raunchy, outrageous fun. If you have an appetite for this particular kind of absurdity, you won't be disappointed

10/10

reviewText: Saints Row The Third is Volitions third entry in the openworld gaming genre. Having just finished Saints Row 2 and immediately diving right into Saints Row The Third I have to say that this game is an absolutely fantastic continuation of the series. Without getting into the story, which is quite good by the way, you are quickly thrust into some of the most over-the-top action movie like sequences from the first minute of the game which hopefully sets the pace for the rest of the title. Fans of the series will find many things familiar while also having some new elements to deal with as well. I'm proud to say that the gameplay, some factors of which I had a problem with in the previous title, has been greatly refined as the driving, fighting and shooting are intuitive and silky smooth. Graphically this game is one of the most beautiful open world titles out there...I've yet to complete but a handful of the earliest missions in the game because I'm spending most of my time just exploring this wonderfully crafted open-world environment. Highly recommended!!!

reviewText:
Considering this is the only installment I've ever played, I must say I'm a bit upset with myself for choosing this game to start with because it's literally the pinnacle of the sandbox ganster genre. There's really no where else to go but down from here regardless of which game I play next in the series.

It's got just about everything you could ask for, great selection of clothing and customization, good variety of weapons, both useful and novelty. It's easy to navigate around the map and the GPS is very well detailed. The map size is also just the right amount of large... it never really seemed overwhelming to me even from the start. Games like GTA and Crackdown just annoyed me with all of their collectables and cluster, this game does it right.

There's plenty of side quests and optional missions to partake in so you'll deinitely be getting your money out of it. The humor is just the right amount of juvenile... you can avoid it completely if you wish to do so. It's over the top and meant to be a parody of sandbox gangster genre games and it definitely delivers. The DLC also adds a lot to the game but can get lost in the mix if you've never played the core game first... I might be basing some of this review on that, so make sure to pick up a complete pack on sale.

The finale is also hilarious with a well known 80's pop song playing while you finish the final mission... One of the more satisfying game endings I've seen.

reviewText: Years after taking Stilwater for their own, the Third Street Saints have evolved from street gang to household brand name, with Saints sneakers, Saints energy drinks and Johnny Gat bobble head dolls all available at a store near you. The Saints are kings of Stilwater, but their celebrity status has not gone unnoticed. The Syndicate, a legendary criminal fraternity with pawns in play all over the globe, has turned its eye on the Saints and demands tribute. Refusing to kneel to the Syndicate, you take the fight to a new city, playing out the most outlandish gameplay scenarios ever seen. Strap it on.

reviewText:
An absolutely wild game, riddled with a lot of cheesy humorous taglines. It may not purposely have a more serious storyline, yet it leans more towards a rather melodramatic badassery. The game itself in terms of features, is rich. You'll have a huge variety of customization opportunities to form your character to just the way you imagined it.
This applies to the fact that you will also provide your character a personality, with choice of voice, the way they compliment and/or taunt, etc.

The controls are kind on you, incredibly beginner-friendly with some room for mastering. The aiming is great but quickly becomes irrelevant as you can upgrade your firearms to carry explosive bullets for instance, which has a fatal spread, hence the lack of necessity of aiming, unless you're all about sniper rifles.

The vehicle customization is beyond nonsensical, but in a pleasing way. You can customize almost any vehicle, I have yet come across a vehicle that cannot be customized, but having that said, I have yet ridden all vehicles into the tuning garage either.

Personally I'd certainly recommend this game for anyone that are looking for an absurdly inappropiate playground, to indulge your absolute bizarre fantasies, under any catergory, you can just about make whatever you please out of the game. You sick f*ck.

Oh and also the graphics is speechless. At least for my standards.

reviewText:
There was rarely a game over the last 8-9 years that impacted me so much that i'd consider the characters and the story to be some of the best i've ever encountered. I play games for 25 years now and due to my collection habit i have consoles going back to the late 70's and i played a ton of games but for the past 10 years there was rarely a game that had characters that stuck to my mind and became favourites of mine like Sonic, Duke Nukem, Alex Kidd or Super Mario did before. Saints Row started out as a pretty mediocre GTA version but over time it developed it's own identity and went away from competing with GTA and instead went into the comedy department, something that been missing over the last 1 or 2 decades in gaming. Everything today tries to be as realistic as possible, simulating every aspect of real life while the fun of gaming relies in doing absurd, unrealistic things.

In some ways when i had to compare games to music, GTA is like the 90's with the dreaded grunge and alternative style: a lot of melodramatic moments, humour is of the black genre and often a bit too serious and realistic for the humour to work (the torture scene in GTA V was a moment the developers clearly wanted as satire but they missed their mark and it came across as too realistic and juvenile.
Saints Row the Third is Glam/Sleaze Metal of the 80's: Don't take it serious but join the fun. It's Party all night long on a Livewire Nightrain into a Fantasy World of comic characters. You lead a rock star gangster group that robs a bank...and fails which is the introduction of you going trough an airplane full of gangsters only to parachute down...
and that's only the beginning of a rollercoaster ride that involes a belgium guy, clones, mexican wrestlers who will deliver a montreal screw job on you and a lot of crazy moments.

The missions are diverse, you have the standard drive there
date: shoot this" missions only to next roll in a big yarn ball around town to jump ino an airplane and do your best Top Gun impression while saving a pimp....by using him lilke a horse. The whole game is beyond insane and that is awesome.\n\nCouple that with a great soundtrack that has various radio stations with adverts and disaster news by jane valderama and of course you can create your very own mixtape by taking songs from all stations and combine them. Importing songs is sadly forbidden but the mixture of classical music
hoursPlayed: rock and metal as well as hip hop
voteText: electronic should satisfy everybody and while i'm as far removed from being a fan of rap and hip hop music i have to say that jumping from a helicopter onto an apartment on top of a skyscraper only to shoot a ton of people while "Power" from kanye west is playing is awesome.\n\nAll the NPCs are also fun
helpfulPercent: they have great voice actors and Pierce Washington singing "What i got" from Sublime with your Player Character who is fully customizable and can be either male or female with various different voices for each gender
votesHelpful: is hilarious all the time. The reaming characters are also awesome
votesTotal: you have Rob Van Dam as color commentator on a wacky show
votesFunny: you have Hulk Hogan as a mexican wrestler and Burt Reynolds as Mayor or Stillwater. It's top notch.\n\nAnd going back to GTA: Unlike Rockstars game
commentsCount: the Plane and Helicopter controls actually work and it's fun to fly around imitating Top Gun and of course it wouldn't be Saints Row if there weren't a lot of wacky Cars and Air vehicles (Salem!)\n\nI can't say anything negative about this game

reviewText:
So I was always sceptical to play the saints row franchise, so very enamoured and snooty with pretty much everything Rockstar has done with GTA. I thought to myself, 'A ridiculous, tongue-in-cheek slapstick take on sandbox criminal gaming? Pshaw, not for me, good sir.‚Äô And then I would doff my invisible top hat and saunter out of the room like a royal prick.

Anyway I‚Äôve played through Saints Row 2 and 3 now and god damn I couldn‚Äôt have been more wrong. I made the mistake of assuming that slapstick and ridiculous were synonymous with lazy and cheap. On the contrary, what I‚Äôve been playing is a very polished product, with a dedication to freshness and humour. Not the kind of humour Rockstar is throttling, but instead something that is unashamed to be silly, but in a super sleek, sexy kind of way. It owns it, and just because it dares to be silly doesn‚Äôt mean that it doesn‚Äôt care to do it classily.

I recommend SR2 for the remarkable grit in its story, and 3 for how smooth and polished (and funny) it is. Give it a shot. Then track down your friend and play it again co-op. Then teach your pet to use a mouse and keyboard and play it again, only this time videoing the pet and uploading it to youtube. ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• would sell.

reviewText:
Pros'n'Cons Reviews

+ Super crazy game design, where you can do what-the-hell-ever you want to.
+ Great variety in vehicles. This doesn't apply to cars, which are dull and generic, but holy crap, the other stuff. You want to hijack a jet and bomb the city? Go. Do some rampage with a pixelated tank? Go, go, go. Drive an armed helicopter? Sure. And all those crazy vehicles.
+ Customization. You can literally do everything with your character. Build her/him up from the ground. Buy the craziest clothes or well...you can just run around butt naked. Upgrade the gang or tune your car. The variety is wide here, but in character customization is almost limitless.
+ Mini-games, mini-games everywhere! There are some activities that you won't see anywhere else. Ride along with a tiger, do some drug trafficking, jump under cars to earn money with your insurance, racing with the unimaginable vehicles (yes, Tron mini-game, we are talking about you), destroy cars and citizens while driving a quad set on fire (!!!) or just blow up the city as such. Whoa, even typing those makes us excited.
+ The co-op campaign is a great addition to the game. Yes, it's not very polished, and there are missions where the second player feels like a third wheel, but even then, playing with a buddy is always fun.
+ The game isn't the most beautiful, but still holds up and the characters designs support the crazy game design very well.

~ Steelport is great, but it's very under utilized. By the time we've finished the campaign we didn't know the locations of the most important places. Simply the game doesn't teach you the city. There's always the GPS, so don't even look at the road while driving.
~ The characters in the game fit into the Saints world. They would be ridiculous and bad in any other game, but this is different. Luckily the more annoying characters get fewer screen time".
~ Open world sand box games tend to have long single player modes. Not Saints Row the Third. The campaign can be finished in about 10-12 hours. It could be a negative point
date: but the activities and other mini-games will keep you in the game for a good number of hours.\n\n- The story starts off interestingly
recommended: but soon falls becomes generic with frustrating and pointless missions that doesn't add anything to the experience (expect the progress in the story
hoursPlayed: of course).\n- The AI is really atrocious. Your companions get stuck often and the enemies just stand there to get shot without any resistance. Strategy is non-existent
voteText: when they see you
helpfulPercent: they try shoot and kill you
votesHelpful: mostly without success. And if we are at enemies...\n- ... they're bulletsponges. A simple footsoldier takes a clip from your handgun before he dies. You can help this with upgrading your weapons
votesTotal: but event then
votesFunny: the enemies will get stronger as you progress. On a side note
commentsCount:
your character also takes a dozen clip to die. Jumping into a room and executing a massacre just stops being fun after a couple of hours.
- The new city is big and open but you can never say that it's living. You get the feeling that there are random stuff happening all the time but without rules or consequences. Steelport definitely isn't a city where you just want to wander around and spend time. Simply there's too much silliness happening around you to feel "home".

Time to beat: 11 hours.
In one word: Crazy
On P'n'C scale: Fun Time
Must give points: 80"

reviewText:
***WARNING***
CONTAINS EXPLICITE LANGUAGE AND SPOILERS!!
(Well, contained explicite language.  Thanks for the censor Steam.)

Like Grand Theft Auto you start out as a small time thug trying to work your way up in organized crime.  Wait, that's not right, you're a ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•in' baller! You're head of the world‚Äôs greatest street gang/media conglomerate/‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• tasting energy maker.  That is, until another gang knocks you down to nothing and like Grand Theft Auto you start out as a small time thug trying to work your way up in organized crime.

Rather than try to out grit the GTA franchise, Saint's Row goes for humor.  It is a ridiculous satire of other video games, corporate culture, politics and pop culture.  If high brow or subtle humor isn't your thing, there are plenty of ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• and fart jokes, too.  The dialog and cuts scenes are hilarious, and change slightly depending on which voice you pick for your character.  I‚Äôve played the game up to the ‚ÄúWhat I got‚Äù sing along four times just to hear what the different characters say.

While the game doesn‚Äôt take the story or characters seriously, it does take the game play seriously.  The controls are responsive and intuitive.  It‚Äôs also one of the few games I‚Äôve played that let you switch between gamepad and keyboard and mouse on the fly without problems.  The challenges and mini games are fun and there is enough variety to keep it from becoming monotonous.  The top level perks are game breaking, but it‚Äôs not like you‚Äôre forced to buy them (as if you could pass up 0% damage from bullets.)  My favorite part is the unarmed power attacks, each one is some form of nut shot or ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• punch.

In conclusion, I can‚Äôt say it‚Äôs the best (or funniest) game ever, but nothing else comes to mind.

reviewText: Saints Row 2 and now The Third are what I wish the modern GTA games were: dedicated to  being a total sociopath and causing supervillain-caliber mayhem upon the world. Saints Row 2 was significantly less graphically advanced than GTA IV, but between the new engine of The Third and the slightly cartoon-y art stylization that's no longer an issue. It doesn't have quite as many character customization options as 2, and Steelport is less geographically diverse than Stillwater.\n\nBut the PC version of SR3 runs flawlessly (it's not a janky port like 2 for PC) and features drop-in co-operative play throughout the entire game,which every sandbox" game should have but few do. The story and missions owe a lot to Shoot 'Em Up/Crank-type cinema
date: aka THE BEST CINEMA. Truly proof that games ARE art; why in the Horde/‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•d Mode you prove it! But the best thing Saints Row The Third has over GTA4 is that it doesn't have THE ABSOLUTE ALL-TIME WORST CAR HANDLING PHYSICS IN GAMING HISTORY like GTA 4."

reviewText:
Fair warning, this is a VERY tongue in cheek game similar to GTA, if you haven't got a sense of humour then this isn't the game for you.

I bought this in the 'Saints Row Ultimate Franchise Pack' when it was on special and I must say, this is the BEST purchase I have made on Steam so far (this game marks my 43rd game I have played via Steam at the time of writing).

I enjoyed the GTA series games but looking back on them I would have to say I enjoyed this more.  I can say the same for the Far Cry series too.  I suppose I could add Just Cause to the list it beats but I have only played 3 hours of JC2 after getting a little tired of it, the same can't be said for SR3 though, it made me want to come back for more and more!

Saints Row 2 was indeed a poor port in the fact that driving was fairly hard as the game played at an increased speed.  Saints Row 3 look excellent though and I encountered no problems (yet to play Co-op though).

The activities are extremely fun, enough to replayable for the enjoyment of them.

I look forward to playing SR4 soon!

reviewText: Saints preserve us, this game is insane!\n\nSAINTS ROW THE THIRD is the most unpretentious game I‚Äôve played to date. It aims to be a gloriously over the top thrill ride and it succeeds with great aplomb. From start to finish it‚Äôs all-out mayhem. Nowhere else do you get the opportunity to batter someone with a huge adult toy or drive around town with an angry tiger in the passenger seat. Few games have actually made me laugh out loud but SRTT did. There are some truly hilarious moments and plenty of dry dialogue. The one-liners are delivered with perfection by the voice actors (I chose the English voice for the playable character ‚Äì voiced by Robin Atkin Downes, I believe ‚Äì and it fitted seamlessly). There have been criticisms that story missions feel more like side missions and I can understand this concern. But story is not really what this game is about. There has to be a narrative of sorts but it‚Äôs the freewheeling craziness of the gameplay that makes this game a joy. Graphically the game is pretty good without being notable. Steelport is nicely realised but some of the character models are less impressive. The soundtrack is worth a note as it includes some fantastic music from just about every genre imaginable. It may not be to everyone‚Äôs taste but if you fancy 15+ hours of riotous pandemonium (plus however many hours of coop, although I suspect it might get old quite quickly once you‚Äôve finished the campaign and experienced all the hilarity and craziness) then you can‚Äôt go far wrong with this game. 4/5

reviewText:
The Plot:

Saints Row: The Third takes place in a city called Steel Port in which it's ruled by three gangs, the Morning Star, the Deckers and the Luchadores. The enemies you fight throughout the game consist of the same 4 NPC models for each gang. They've created an excuse for themselves by claiming that they're all a product of cloning.

Optimization:

This game is optimized for AMD video cards. If you're using a Nvida card you're going to be experiencing significantly lower frame rate and random frame drops.

Currency system:

Money in Saints Row The Third practically flows like water. You recieve money for killing enemies, completing missions, completing challenges, barnstorming and through a multitude of glitches to reach to the money limit of $20,000,000. There's one barn storming location in particular that gives you $12,333 if you fly through it sideways.

The Notority System:

There's no arrest system, no sneak system, you cannot bribe the police or outrun your nortirety. No matter what you do whether it be as small as punching a civilian or as extreme as slaughtering hundreds of innocent people, the police will attempt to kill you. The ONLY way to lose your notority is to walk into a store or safehouse owned by the Saints or attempt to wait until your notority fades. However, you're likely to commit even more crimes when you're running for your life from machine guns, snipers, attack choppers and tanks.

Vehicle Thefts:

Within the Saints Book there's 34 vehicle thefts needed to be completed to get the 100%. Volition made it to where you get a higher notority level as you progress in the vehicle thefts, just to frustrate the player I assume. Unfortunately, there is no way of outrunning the norority so this side activity is practically getting to the checkpoint before the vehicle explodes. While driving, enemies will constantly spawn within feet ahead of you, almost guranteeing a crash. I will provide a demonstrition video at the bottom of this review.

Assassination Missions:

There's 36 assassination missions needed to be completed for the 100%. These are fairly easy usually consisting of doing a particular thing to lure out the target. However, some require for you to gain gang nortority in certain areas of the map and if you've already taken over that part of the map, you're going to need to complete it on an earlier save or in a friend's game. Towards the end of the assassination missions  Burt Renolds will ask you to kill a particular person. This person is the Concerned Citizen you've been doing assassinations for up until that point, DO NOT KILL HIM UNTIL YOU'VE COMPLETED ALL OF HIS ASSASSINATION MISSIONS FOR THE CONCERNED CITIZEN. Killing him before will make the 100% unobtainable. Sadly, nobody warned me ahead of time.

Character Customization:

Character customization is one of the few things that other games need to take a page from when it comes to Saints Row The Third. Though lacking a skin tone slider, the game allows you to select from a variety of skin tones and options. Unfortunately, there's always an insanely repetitive tune playing in all of the Image as Designed stores while customizing your character.

Vehicle Customization:

Unlike the Saints Row franchise's previous title Saints Row 2, you can no longer listen to the song playing on the radio while editing your vehicle, you must listen to the same repetitive tune. You also no longer get a view of what your vehicle looks like while you're inside Rim Jobs, instead you'll be viewing your vehicle infront of a black background with tire skids moving left and right.

CO-OP:

Co-op is a buggy though humorous experience. Some activities will randomly teleport you out of your vehicle that you're otherwise not supposed to exit, causing you to fail missions. Co-op partners and most NPCs will sometimes get stuck in buildings, vehicles, and other clutter within the game, almost ensuring death.


Summary:

Other than completing assassination missions, vehicle thefts, challenges, purhcasing all upgrades, finding all collectables and completing all of the missions, there really isn't much else to do. Just run and gun until your map is fully purple.


| Saints Row The Third Combat Demonstration |

reviewText:
Aside from the publisher's sad fate, Saint's Row The Third is a fun open world game where you play the (visually self-defined) boss of your own gang and get to wreck the whole fictional city, Steelport with little remorse. And unlike the GTA series, this game is moving forward in a very different direction away from the all the seriousness and realism about the genre and into a world where law has no meaning in it.
You will have awesome (but rather evil/cruel/crude) killmoves, a variety of weapons and vehicles to play with, and lots of customisation to go around.
If you don't mind its weird humour, the sex jokes, the cartoonish looks and lots and lots of seriously rediculous antics, this game is a good alternative for you.
Just don't practice those things IRL. Definitely a no-no.

Note that I find the multiplayer co-op on PC having rather laggish connectivity, so do take note if you wish to attempt it.

reviewText:
Quite possibly one of my favourite games ever, Saint's Row III is serious about messing around.
Aim of the game: shoot stuff, chainsaw stuff, explode stuff, run around naked while hitting stuff with a ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•/baseball bat.
The possibilities are endless. Regardless of how many times the game glitched on me or just plain disturbed me I couldn't stay away. The fast paced combination of shooting, running, driving, flying, skydiving in a panda suit with a chainsaw, I just couldn't resist the simple, mindless fun of it all.

Screwing around in sandbox mode is certainly more exciting than a mojority of the story and that's OK because the game is simply incredible.

Flawed and Unfaithful to the previous games as SR3 is, it is still a brilliant game and totally worth your money.

SO BUY IT.

reviewText:
Having never played the previous two games I went into this expecting a GTA clone. I was pleasently suprised when it had enough of it's own thing going to get myself and the friend who got it for a multiplayer co-op game to actually have a lot of fun going through it.

By the time you beat the game you should be a high enough level to be a one man wrecking crew if you have spent your money appropriatly. Which can make the final confrontation kinda lackluster because you are so close to immortal it's not even funny.

The gameplay is solid with the exception of a few of the activities you have to do. They are not exactly explained well and can possibly force you to complete them with trial and error. Or go look up how they are done.

The graphics for this game though a little dated now are still pretty solid and hold up as long as you remember the game is several years old.

Last of all I highly recomend playing this game with a friend in co-op mode over just a solo play through because you and your friend can get many a great laugh out of the pop culture references and just creating shananigans for your co-op partner to deal with.
