reviewText:
I have fond memories of playing Saints Row and Saints Row 2 on the Xbox 360 when I was younger.  Although outdated by today's standards, I had a lot of fun playing them.  They were open-world crime games with fun gameplay and a zany sense of humor.

But in my opinion, they pale in comparison to Saints Row: The Third.  Right from the first mission, I could tell that this game was going to be a lot of fun.  Saints Row: The Third follows the story of the Third Street Saints, a street gang turned into pop culture icons.  Unfortunately, their popularity becomes their downfall after a bank heist goes awry.

Much like the first two games, this game has you build up your criminal empire by stealing turf from rival gangs.  Doing missions and side quests helps you gain control of the city.  You don't have to completely drive out the other gangs to finish the game, but it can be satisfying to see the map filled with Saints territory.

As I said, the story is very similar to the first two games.  However, this isn't a bad thing.  The game is split into 3 acts.  Act 1 is typical Saints Row, but Acts 2 and 3 throw in things that haven't been seen in Saints Row games before.  I don't want to go into too many details for fear of spoiling the story. I will say this though: the game's soundtrack really adds to the missions in the game.  Near the end of the game, there is a certain wrestling match that plays some very inspirational music and makes it absolutely hilarious.

Arguably, gameplay is the most important part of open-world crime games.  This is where this game really shines.  The gunplay is fun, melee combat is fun, and driving/flying work very well.  The only problem I had with the gameplay is that getting into vehicles such as the tank or VTOL can be a challenge -- if you aren't at EXACTLY the spot the game wants to be at, your characters does an odd movement and won't get into the vehicles.  This is especially annoying if you are almost dead and trying to escape.  But, that is a very minor complaint in the grand scheme of things.

Lastly, I think the mission-based DLC is worth buying.  Get the season pass and skip all of the cosmetic ones (unless you're interested in that).  The mission-based DLC adds a decent length to the game and all three of them are a lot of fun.

I enjoyed this game so much that I played it through to 100% completion. I haven't done that in a game since I got 100% of the achievements in BioShock on Xbox 360.  I haven't tried the co-op mode, but I imagine that it is very fun as well.  If you like open-world crime games that don't take themselves too seriously, then you should definitely buy Saints Row: The Third.

reviewText: Saint's Row the Third is the game your mother warned you about. It is over the top vulgar, hilarious, obscene, and fun. It's like GTA if GTA recognized that the only reason it was fun is because of the mayhem you can cause in its sandbox environment. Nearly every campaign mission is designed with this in mind, often offering you infinite ammo with explosives and early access to highly overpowered weapons of mass destruction like aircraft, UAV drone missiles, tanks, etc.. It also has a cheats function (remember those?) so you can play how you'd like to. The music soundtrack is excellent, incorporating everything from Sublime, to hip-hop, to House (courtesy of deadmau5), to metal...the radio stations are all a joy to listen to and the menu music and customization music is also enjoyable. Speaking of customization, this game caters to everyone's need to play dressup. Unlike GTA you can customize just about everything about your character - tattoos, black eyes, build, hair style - it rivals The Elder Scrolls in this regard. You can even give yourself custom taunts and celebrations, *and* pick your voice actor. The guns are upgradable and vary nicely, and you can spend your hard-earned cash not only on property but also upgrades for your character like increased health, dual-wielding, all the way up to infinite ammo. Even your cars can be upgraded and modified, want to punt 24 rims on your Prius? Go ahead! Why not add underglow and a modded engine while you're at it! I was pleasantly surprised with this game since I'm not a huge fan of sandboxes (I don't like collecting arbitrary stuff
date:
which you can in this game too - sex dolls in fact) but the sense of humor and joking atmosphere of Saints Row easily places it as my favorite sandbox game I've yet played.

Pros:

Humor
Sountrack
Customization factor
Weapons (upgradable)
Outrageousness
Fun factor
Variable gameplay
Custscene direction

Cons:

Stupid follower AI
No real 'redeeming' factor to this game

While going around blowing stuff up and smacking people with a giant purple ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• to a hip-hop soundtrack is fun there isn't anything deeper here. As I said
recommended: this is the game your mother warned you about
hoursPlayed: there isn't really any gaming as art here (you could be pretentious and say the over the top outrageousness is but
voteText: whatever) so there isn't any redeeming quality to this game and
helpfulPercent: as usual
votesHelpful: follower AI is incompetent at best
votesTotal: but this game was a lot of fun and very relaxing. The gameplay is solid and varied (lots of cool side missions to do) and overall I had a great time. If you like sandboxes it's a must buy and even if you don't you'll still probably have a lot of fun with the campaign like I did. A-"

From the fantastic use of licensed music, quality voice acting and general style of the game to the mayhem of co-op there is nothing I don't love about this game.

reviewText:
It is my sincere belief that this game is the most fun you can have with your pants on - although pants, as always, are optional.

I steered clear of this game for ages because I thought it sounded 'silly'. Having since played it (Steam Sales, I love you) I can tell you that it's not only 'silly', but is also 'excellently voice acted' and, frankly, by far the funniest and most charismatic game I've ever played.

Good characterisation, and a game that knows it's a game, and loves that about itself.

If this game were a person, it would be a spliced clone containing the DNA of Teddy Roosevelt and Chuck Norris, and would also have lazer cannon arms, one robotic eye, and a healing factor.

It's not perfect (some of the missions seem to be glitchy), but it's the probably closest we'll get in a game desigined by other humans.

Just be aware that one mission (The Belgian Problem) needs you to be in windowed mode, because new computers are too fast.

I award this game 31 out of 10, because maths is for losers.

reviewText:
Saints Row: The Third is an exciting open world game which places you square in the middle of the most crazy city ever imagined. If you liked GTA but found it too serious Saints Row is for you. Zombies, clones, space travel and more make it quite an exciting and addictive game.

Pros of the game:
- Quirky and unusual story, much less serious than most AAA games.
- Great level of player customization and vehicle customization.
- Large number of side missions, collectable and other fun time wasters to keep the game interesting after the main story is cmplete.

reviewText:
Before the credits roll you'll catsit a tiger, play a hilarious text adventure, get a sex change, hack up Mexican wrestlers with a chainsaw, visit a Tron-like computer world, and participate in many other ridiculous leisure activities. Saints Row the Third can be accused of being many things, but repetitive isn't one of them.

Some games create atmospheric worlds that attempt to draw you in with moving stories about characters seeking a second chance, or cast you as troubled superheroes who push themselves to the limit to fight evil. Saints Row: The Third is not like those games. Rather, it's the kind of game that gives you weapons called apocafists with which you can punch people, instantly making them explode in a bloody mess. The Third won't impress you with knockout visuals, move you with an absorbing story, or engage you with challenging combat. What it does, better than just about any game before, is embrace the idea of an open world as a place for play, constantly giving you access to awesome new toys and providing you with no shortage of exciting opportunities to use them.

One thing you definitely shouldn't ignore is the main story. Within just the first few missions, you plummet out of a plane and into an airborne shoot-out, skydive into a penthouse that belongs to a rival gang, use a UAV drone to call in guided missiles on tanks, and more. The missions eventually become a bit predictable for a while, serving as introductions to the other activities and diversions available to you in Steelport. But before long, they get wild again, packing in numerous surprises before culminating in one of two outrageous final missions.

Saints Row: The Third is buoyed to great heights by terrific mission design and by the remarkable assortment of vehicles and weapons it gives you with which to take over Steelport. Whether you're buying up property to increase your hourly income, cruising the city in your favorite vehicle to collect photo ops, drug packages, and sex dolls, or punching people to bits with those crazy apocafists, there's rarely a dull moment. Saints Row: The Third succeeds tremendously at delivering its unique brand of raunchy, outrageous fun. If you have an appetite for this particular kind of absurdity, you won't be disappointed

10/10

reviewText: I may be a bit late to the party on this one, but I'm not about to pass up a chance to talk about this game. Let me start off by saying that in terms of gameplay and mechanics, the Saints Row series is very similar to Grand Theft Auto, a series which I personally have never really been a fan of. But stealing cars and running over ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•s isn't what makes this game fun; it's the sheer level of ridiculousness that encompasses, well, every damn thing about this game. Whereas GTA tries to keep things realistic and serious to a degree, SR3 tosses that aside in favor of laser shotguns, deadly game shows and a giant weaponized purple phallus. And that's just the beginning. Everything about this game had me both laughing out loud and awkwardly covering my screen whenever the family was around. And the game isn't all about being outrageously insane; there's an interesting storyline, and a world with lots to explore. Add on some fun side missions and a ton of hilarious minigames (such as driving a tiger around town or running in front of cars to claim insurance money), and the result is the most awkward fun you can have.

reviewText:
Excellent game. Very funny and humerous through out the missions. Much better then Gta games with the freedom of what you can do. Alot of memeries can be made when playing with friends in co-op, when you free roam or even do missions. Excellent for playing friends in co-op missions or free roaming.

The first mission is a excellent one it puts you right in the mood of how this game will be straight a way. A great way to tell if you will like it or not. A lot of time can be put into the game completing the campaign or even just earning achieviments and free roaming.

The ending fell a bit short as it was slightly hard and not as entaining than the rest of the missions, no spoilers sorry. you will have to find out your self. But the customization was excellent, you can customize and upgrade your cars to your hearts content. Even with upgrading your abillities was great. You can customize your cribs, your gang, your cars and last but not least your self, as far as clothing and abillities go.

The controls were very nice and easy to learn even for flying aircrafts, a beginner for games can learn the controls nearly instantly. They are very straight forward as far as that goes. The physics are also very well done with the driving and flying, they were very realistic and smooth. I love the fact that you can go sky diving it was awesome.

The weapon range and upgrades for them went forever. From ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• to rocket launchers they had nearly anything you would like to kill someone with. The upgrades for them were awesome going from a cheap shotgun to a fully automatic spaz was awesome to see. Love the fart bomb, just love it.
You will have some great action playing this game. Not many let downs at all. I would give it a 9.8/10 because nothing is perfect but this game does come close to it.

reviewText:
Pros:
Good muliplayer - you can do any campaign mission with your friends
Open world - there's a lot to do in the game besides just playing through the story
Story - Although it is not a super rich story, it is entertaining
Customizable - You can customize car color, car body parts, car wheels, clothes and colors, gangs, etc

Cons:
Unrealistic physics - the game's physics are incredibly unrealistic, your guy flips and bounces from cars and explosions.
Story - You cannot replay the story after you beat the game, you have to start over on a new save
DLC - There's lots of DLC available, but its around $2-3 for a few new clothes or a new car or two

Notes:
The game as a whole seems like kind of a joke. If you're looking for a serious game, this may not be for you. If you're looking to just mess around and have fun by yourself or with friends, you'll probably enjoy Saints Row: The Third a lot

reviewText:
A satire of the commercialization of gangster fandom and silly Japanese gimmicks. And if a satire it is not, then it describes how much all 'hoes' (women) are ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•s and how 'pimps' (procurers) are all cool and funny.

The game features a slick presentation, funny character designs, witty dialogues, and hilariously well directed cut-scenes.

Unfortunately, the gameplay is extremely repetitive and rarely offers any challenge at all. There are plenty of activities but most are just dreadfully boring.

The game also suffers from various random crashes, frame stuttering, and crappy console input mappings (e.g., open door / pick up item / grab / throw / revive / answer / start activity: all in one button!).

The first Saints Row had a plot, a coherence in the city layout and its gangs, challenging situations, in-depth player customization and better immersion. Where SR3 just surpasses in silliness and graphics.

Note that the game contains mature sexual themes and mosaic blurred full frontal nudity, so you may want to reconsider before gifting this game to random kids.

Also, it is best to finish the game at least once before getting the DLC's, since there's no way to disable them, and some DLC completely ruin the gameplay since they're basically cheat codes.

reviewText: Saints Row: The Third, an open-world third person shooter released for the Xbox 360, PS3, and PC is a game that will give you a few laughs here and there, but other than that, it doesn't really do much more. Don't get me wrong, I like this game, it's just that when I look at it from a technical standpoint, it doesn't try anything new. Sure, the jokes are funny, and some of the activites are hilarious, but let me tell you why it isn't a game that will be remembered for years to come.\n\nAfter the events of Saints Row 2, you (The Boss) have become a celebrity icon, and the Saints name is now a household brand. With people like Pierce in your crew selling energy drinks, sneakers and other merchandise, it all seems well and good. But as the Saints reach higher and higher to fame, a legendary criminal fraternity known as The Syndicate" has noticed the Saints and demand they give up. The Saints refuse this offer

reviewText: Note: I also own this on console and have played TONS of hours and beat the game multiple times. Don't let my hours on Steam fool you.\n\nIn my mind Saints Row: The Third is the funnest in the franchise. It's not the best story of the franchise (I think that's Saints Row 2 in my book), but it's the funnest. In fact it might be one of the funnest games I've ever played.. for the simple fact of how crazy it really is. It NEVER takes itself seriously.. you can upgrade your pistols to have explosive rounds, beat people with a giant purple ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• baseball bat, throw a fart in a jar" at people
date: run around completly naked and you can even create a full on zombie to play as complete with a zombie voice! The humour is awesome and the gameplay is great. The only thing is that towards the end of the game you can become TOO overpowered.. with "upgrades" that are basically cheat codes... allowing unlimited ammo
hoursPlayed: etc. but you don't have to buy them so it's really your choice. Overall an awesome game definitly worth the money."

reviewText:
Huge step back from SR2 but still, it's a good game.

PROS:
+ Funny missions.
+ You don't need to make respect bar full before starting missions anymore.
+ Quite good radio stations.
+ Wacky weapons and vehicles.
+ New activities.
+ New characters (Pierce is also much more useful character than in SR2).
+ Customization options.
+ Community and achievements.
+ Various choises with different awards.
+ Upgrade system.
+ Much better optimization.
+ Quite good mission packs.
+ Modding.

CONS:
- Much worse and shorter storyline.
- Much less things to do in the open world.
- Much smaller and more boring city.
- Very few easter eggs.
- Lots of missing characters and unfinished plots (Shaundi is also much worse than in SR2).
- Shaundi is an annoying ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• - she's completely different than in SR2.
- No mission nor cutscene replay.
- No minigames like Zombie Uprising (there are slot machines but you can't use them).
- Much less variety of pedestrians (they also don't fight back, like they did in SR2).
- Plenty of bugs.
- Quite weak car damage system.
- There's no way to toggle upgrades.
- Lots of useless and pointless DLCs.
- Unlockable Pack DLC which completely destroys the game.

I rate it 6,5 out of 10. It's fun but incomparable to SR2.

reviewText: An Over-the-Top Action Game!This game certainly doesn't take itself as seriously as Saints Row 2, but that doesn't stop itself from being a huge amount of fun. It has an enmjoyable story-line and even more customisation options for your character. The graphics are nice and the game run smoothly. There are co-op modes available that allow you to play through the story with a friend or in mini-games outside the main game. However, once you reach the end-game, there is almost to replay value unless you start a new game as there are no enemies left to kill (except for the police/miltary if you create a riot) and if you max out your upgrades you can basically become a god with infinite ammo and health. Other than that this game is deifnitely worth buying.

reviewText:
Total Playtime to Completion: 29hrs

I want to put on record that this game is LOTS of fun.

The one thing I can say about Saints Row the Third (SRTT) is how quickly it makes you forget your expectations and just have FUN.  It wants you to be random and just enjoy the game without consequences; something I suspect Volition went out of their way to ensure. The controls (aside from the still foreign weapon select) are tight and the controller integration is very solid (Thanks Team!) so it made SRTT a very enjoyable/playable experience to me.

The story is just hilarious, the graphics are still holding their own and the driving is just fantastic compared to other titles (I am looking at you GTA). In fact, every game should have a quick steal option for cars modelled after SRTT. This series has always done Character Creation well but this time around it is just MENTAL. There is a slider for EVERYTHING! You can truly make your character your own which is just an awesome finishing touch for this game.

My only two complaints with the game are prehaps the side missions could have had some degree of integration with the main story (aside from just being fun things to do) and that the story missions (whilst being selectable in the phone) didn't have a clear indication of which order you should play them in. I kind of just shotgunned an entire characters worth of story in a single hit and got a bit lost until I realised it tied in with other missions I hadn't played yet. These are just minor gripes however and you might have a completely different outlook on these issues.

So, should you buy it? Yes. It is cheesy, over the top wild action and I had a great time playing it. Well done Volition!

8/10.

Also Burt Reynolds.

reviewText: A little more excessively violent then some of the other games Ive played in the past but so far has a good story line and some great voice acting. Weapons system and using the XBOX 360 Controller on my laptop is taking some getting used to and some of the objectives in game are a bit difficult (First scene trying to take down the helicopter) And then the second scene where your jumping out of the airplane - The game does get credit from me by detecting if your stuck - It shows you a reminder of the controls and what to do next. Was also surprised my laptop ran it reasonably - Had to use the Direct X 9 mode and turn down some of the details to get a playable framerate but all in all I've had a reasonable experience.\n\nA warning to parents - This game has excessive swearing and allows you to freely kill other people that would get you arrested and possibly put in prison for life - Or even a worse sentence. Parents should preview this game using online video sources before deciding to let their kids  play or purchase this game.

reviewText:
Certainly one of the best open world games out there. What makes this game unique is that it takes the options out of the window of any normal open world game out there and recreates it much better.

Starting off with the character selection, you are given lots of options for clothing, taunts or even the voice of your character. The missions are well constructed and in different missions you are able to do different actions such as flying through a plane and killing everyone inside it, going out the end and the plane exploding to landing on a skyscraper with a parachute and killing everyone in a party to claim the building as yours.

Not only the missions are well constructed, but also the voices and the dialogue between characters. I feel like the dialogue brings you into the game because they are out of the ordinary you would expect in an open world game. From singing a song in a car with Pierce to making funny jokes between characters.

Out of missions, you can hit up a car or plane delivery or just hit up your homie for backup in a gun fight. This game even has a challenge system which allows you to play the game for longer by having to land a parachute in a specific spot multiple times or having to jump over multiple bridges in the game. The challenges also include different minigames such as Insurance Fraud where you have to ragdoll between cars and get the highest score possible to destroying everything with a tank. This you did not expect, did you?

Of course in this game you have a co-op so you can do missions with a friend whilst talking on a microphone.
The disadvantages come from the co-op side of the game as once you create a co-op game you have to host the game from your local machine as there are no servers for SR3 itself. If your Internet is bad then your co-op partner will also suffer from stuttering. Also for co-op you are not able to chat in-game apart from messaging each other from Steam and having to Click Shift+Tab everytime you want to send a message which is very annoying.

Moving out of co-op, this game is also poorly optimized so if you don't have good specifications for your computer, you can wish about playing this game. Please be sure to check whether you meet the specified requirements first before purchasing this.

But in overall, excluding the co-op disadvantages the game is well presented and it brings open world games to the whole new level since it is not focused on the missions itself mainly. 8/10 for this game.

reviewText: Saints Row 3 has a very odd place in my mind. It has been quite a while since I beat the game and for most of it I played LAN coop with a roommate. I remember that we both loved the game and laughed the whole way through it, I remember thinking everything about the game was just pure unadulterated fun and that nothing would be able to top it. Yet now, I look back and really don‚Äôt have any interest in the game. Perhaps the whole Saints Row formula was just a fad and is now past its prime.\n\nI can‚Äôt in good conscious give this game a ‚Äúnot recommend‚Äù because I lost countless hours causing chaos in the vibrant open world of Steel Port. However, I think it‚Äôs fair to warn future shoppers that the humor and gameplay of Saints Row 3 will entertain those it‚Äôs targeted at, but at the same time has the potential to rapidly become stale.

reviewText:
There is very little challenge in the game itself, and the main point seems to be just to do anything you want while racing around in a fast car.  Sounds fun, but actually you get immune to it all pretty fast.
One point I found particularly troublesome is that it only displays the name of an item that you come across as you are wandering about.  You need your chav ‚Äùbling-o-pedia‚Äù there to work out which is best, or you are more than likely to accidentally downgrade, as I did, several times.
Also the game has a very console feel to it and a bewildering array of key presses that vary in function depending what you are doing.
All in all, pretty well executed, and  great for a few minutes if you want to impress your friends with a dose of  chaving"

reviewText: You know what? This game has the best features a game could have. It doesn't take itself too seriously but you can still count on an amazing story. Every single voice you can choose from has its unique dialogue, even the zombie one. You can customize your character as much as you'd like. Customize your gang, your crib, your car, whatever the ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• you'd want to. The game has some really silly guns for your amusement. You wouldn't get bored for quite a bit of time. 20 hours of fun at least guaranteed. Music is amazing, activities are not necessary like they were in SR2 but they are in fact really fun. The only problem I personally had with this game was the fact that the co-op was laggy as hell. If you were thinking of getting this game for the main purpose to play with a friend you would get really disappointed. Otherwise SR3 is the epitome of badassery.

reviewText: As an analogy, I have always seen the Saints Row"-series as the younger
date: funnier and immature brother of the "Grand Theft Auto"-series. This is what the creators of SR probably had in mind when they were making their game. The rate of absurd immaturity isn't necessarily negative
recommended:
au contraire; it creates that light and amusing atmosphere that I've come to expect of Saints Row.

Pros:
+ Very amusing
+ Absurd
hoursPlayed:
though great humour
+ Simple & clean upgrade system
+ Great character & vehicle customisation (which personally always makes the game a lot more fun for me)
+ A lot of diversity (more on this in the cons though)
+ Cool NPCs

Cons:
- Main story arch is too short in my opinion
- Frustrating AI (which is a problem in lots of other games too)
- Although SR likes to mix up the missions and activities
voteText: you might actually feel that the everything is quite repetitive\n- Even though the NPCs are great
helpfulPercent: I think that you should be able to spend more time with them and get to know them better
votesHelpful:
they are after all " your crew"

Conclusion:
Saints Row: The Third is a great successor to the previous game and meets my expectations of the game
votesTotal: which doesn't mean there isn't room for improvement. Playing the game was very satsifying though I doubt I will playing more than two playthroughs
votesFunny: except if my OCD were to kick in and make me want to get all the achievements.\n\nMy score for SR3 would be 7.5/10"

reviewText:
TO BUY OR NOT TO BUY: Saint's Row the Third
by JunkSt‚úÆr

PROS:
‚ú≠Genuinely funny game: it doesn't take itself too seriously
‚ú≠Decent character customization, both cosmetically and skillwise
‚ú≠Features full game co-op
‚ú≠Huge amount of sidequests

CONS:
‚ú≠Game world feels small compared to others of the genre
‚ú≠Some generic bugs, more-so in multiplayer
‚ú≠Simplistic AI

FINAL DECISION: Buy it with a friend. The comedic value of this game skyrockets with a teammate, but may get old during a single player playthrough.

reviewText:
+ Hilariously fun, half of which comes from its wacky humor.
+ Story and characters are alright.
+ Very enjoyable (side) missions.
+ Great co-op which works extremely well. I absolutely recommend playing this game co-op, it's a blast.
+ Lots of vehicles of various types.
+ Good car radio music.

- Terrible AI.
- Mediocre graphics with horrible optimization.
- German version is not compatible with the international version. Which limited my co-op to one person.

Saints Row: The Third, a hilariously over-the-top sandbox game. I definitely recommend picking this one up. Make sure you have a co-op partner.

83/100

reviewText: The often cited, for obvious reasons, comparison between Saints Row and GTA don't really do this game justice. Short if open-world, third-person, gang/crime game there is little else that can be said is the same so that's as far as I'll compare them.\n\nThe best part about this game is that it knows what it is. It knows it isn't gritty or realistic and it panders to that crazy over-the-topness that you know you occasionally want from a game. While there are of course many elements that are normal" (escort missions
recommended: etc) the tight game play and bright
hoursPlayed: colorful world and enemy design makes them enjoyable. Besides as soon as you're done you can go play in traffic or drive around with a tiger in the passengers seat as much as you want (both actual mini-games).\n\nThe game really does a pretty good job of pacing. You start out feeling pretty weak
voteText: avoiding conflict and fleeing from bigger fights
helpfulPercent: but by the end you are running into a military compound because you have an extra case of rockets laying around. It also does a good job of avoiding the trap of over stimulating the player with too much too soon and I really never felt like it was dragging or tired.\n\nOf course there are issues (you can break the money system using an age old method) but at the end of the day this game is just plain FUN
votesHelpful: like games should be. I wholeheartedly recommend buying this game although the best method is probably to wait for the Complete Package to go on sale."

reviewText: You know what? This game has the best features a game could have. It doesn't take itself too seriously but you can still count on an amazing story. Every single voice you can choose from has its unique dialogue, even the zombie one. You can customize your character as much as you'd like. Customize your gang, your crib, your car, whatever the ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• you'd want to. The game has some really silly guns for your amusement. You wouldn't get bored for quite a bit of time. 20 hours of fun at least guaranteed. Music is amazing, activities are not necessary like they were in SR2 but they are in fact really fun. The only problem I personally had with this game was the fact that the co-op was laggy as hell. If you were thinking of getting this game for the main purpose to play with a friend you would get really disappointed. Otherwise SR3 is the epitome of badassery.

reviewText:
Saints Row The Third, in all, is a fantastic game.

Pros
+Great Story
+Many Badass Moments
+Many Levels Of Customization
+Memorable Gameplay
+Hours Of Fun
+Runs Fantastically
+Best Of Them All (Opinion)
+Almost Always On Sale, Cheap

Cons
-Nothing That Happens Makes Sense (thats just the beuty of SR3)
-Too Much Expensive And Not Worth-It DLC

Overall-
9.5/10

Fantastic game, but they suck your money in. The only good DLC's are Gangstas In Space, Trouble With Clones, and Geinkeibowl IIV. Those contain fun addon missions that add 10+ more hours.

Take over the city

The game features territory that either belongs to the 3rd street saints (you), morningstar, luchadores, or deckers. Eliminate drug deals, buy stores, or complete fun activities to take the territory, and see your crew move into your new land. In doing so, get an hourly income so you can upgrade your guy, and more. Have cribs" and safehouses for when you progress through the story

reviewText: This is probably one of the most hilarious and fun games I have ever played. It has a great setting, likeable characters, nice graphics, and is absolutly over-the-top. The story about the struggle of the Third Street Saints against the Syndicate in Steelport is also very engaging and has some pretty funny moments. But if you want, to can just ignore the story for as long as you want and commit vehicular manslaughter by the hundreds, blow s**t up or just run around and explore.\nSimply put, if you like over-the-top humour and Grand Theft Auto, you will like this game. It doesn't take itself seriously whatsoever and doesn't try to be gritty or edgy like GTA.

Since I got all the Saints products in a bundle deal, I have become obsessed with them now...
They are so far the best of the open world gangsta' style play ever. To me, they are what GTA could have been, but with a much less serious note.
This story picks up in a most humerous way, following our gang of miscreants as they journey to a new city, not by choice, and have to pick up from the bottom. But not so far on the bottom. If you finished Saints Row the 2nd you understand that they are not down and out by any means, and you will understand why.
The only thing I am not enjoying as much is that I have all the DLC, which is not a bad thing, but STEAM installs it all from the bundle at once, so I have all these things that would not have been available in a normal first time play through. Some of it could be a bit OP, so I just ignore those items and play straight. I also didnt realize that you could not turn on / off the DLC. As long as you dont begin the game with the addition of the OP vehicles in use you will love the it all.
Looking forward to many many hours here, and just like the other Saints series so far, replayability is HIGH!
EIDT: Duh, realized I could turn off the DLC under properties... So the OP stuff is gone. It also allowed my save game to load fine. I started a new one though since the money was way over the top from the DLC's.
Totally worth it as part of the SR collection.

reviewText:
The storyline is as unrealistic as it gets, within the first 10 minutes, you'll realise this. But, this is definitely not a criticism, It's a compliment. Too many games of this nature are engaging with realism and this game gives you a well needed break, and just lets you relax and have fun. To put it another way, it resembles an action movie (where everything is very unrealistic). The graphics are also a nice touch. Again, non-realistic and cartoonish. It has a nice style that I never get sick of.
The setting has now shifted from Stillwater to Steelport with the Saints now trying to assume control of new territory and the set up is all the same as before. The story carries on from the second game despite a change in location as usual rival gangs occupy the city and the STAG army are sent in to try control things. The main story missions are all well executed despite most been in bonkers territory from gunfights while skydiving right through too becoming a walking toilet (yes I kid you not).
Apart from mission games there are plenty of mini games that you can do in your own time that aren't part of the central story but will help you control more of the city which enables you to make more money to buy more weapons and upgrades and so on. What's also nice is that there are decisions to make along the way that affect the outcome of the game. You can side with an army type organisation and they'll aid you take over parts of the city or you can side with another faction and this will help you in other ways.

reviewText: Saints Row: The Third keeps all the things that made Saints Row 2 so much fun, and now with improved graphics. Ok, so maybe I miss spraying ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• on people, but overall it's still a funtastically over-the-top crazy game of creativity, imagination, and mayhem. Just about anything and everything can be unlocked, customized, or upgraded. There's all kinds of different missions to experience, lots of whacky things to see and hear (and a few things maybe you don't want to see), and plenty of laughs in store. Coop is available once again doubling the fun factor--just try it once and you'll find out what I'm talking about.\n\nFor anyone looking to take life a little less seriously, pick up Saints Row: The Third and you'll be whisked far from the land of reality. But be warned, you may end up with a permanent smile on your face.

reviewText: If you like the Grand Theft Auto style of games, then this is another game you should pick up. The progression system in this game is great. You are always being rewarded with something, for nearly everything you do. The user interface is very well designed and nice look at. No more having to squint your eyes to read things like in GTA. The missions are all a ton of fun and very diverse. You will be doing anything and everything in this game. Nothing is too extreme to be doing as a mission here and that makes it a ton of fun. Expect a lot of mature content in this one though (more than GTA).\n\nIt will last you around 25 hours without the DLC.

reviewText: I have yet to finish the story, but I feel I can give a general recommendation. This is more hallucination than reality. Nothing feels real, and yet there is a certain illusion of reality. If all the violence and many other things were real, than it would take certain personality disorders and worse to enjoy this. I see it as a postmodern take on the GTA genre. All the sexism, killing and crime is so out of proportion that everything collapses in cartoon explosions. Now, it is absurdist and surreal. Saints Row 3 is not meant to be taken seriously simply because it is all surface. Other see this as a psychotic sandbox but there is method to the madness.

reviewText:
Saints Row The Third, in all, is a fantastic game.

Pros
+Great Story
+Many Badass Moments
+Many Levels Of Customization
+Memorable Gameplay
+Hours Of Fun
+Runs Fantastically
+Best Of Them All (Opinion)
+Almost Always On Sale, Cheap

Cons
-Nothing That Happens Makes Sense (thats just the beuty of SR3)
-Too Much Expensive And Not Worth-It DLC

Overall-
9.5/10

Fantastic game, but they suck your money in. The only good DLC's are Gangstas In Space, Trouble With Clones, and Geinkeibowl IIV. Those contain fun addon missions that add 10+ more hours.

Take over the city

The game features territory that either belongs to the 3rd street saints (you), morningstar, luchadores, or deckers. Eliminate drug deals, buy stores, or complete fun activities to take the territory, and see your crew move into your new land. In doing so, get an hourly income so you can upgrade your guy, and more. Have cribs" and safehouses for when you progress through the story

reviewText:
It's kind of strange to make an open-world game whose story & missions are shorter and more concise than its predecessor. Isn't an open-world game about having a ton of stuff to explore and do? Which to me is the conundrum of Saints Row: The Third. It's still a fun game, and recommended, but a lack of content volume (not variety) disappoints after the plethora of activities in Saints Row 2.

+ Good gun-play, character upgrade path, weapon upgrade path.
+ Graphics are really good (DX11) if your machine is powerful enough to turn the settings up (a far render distance is pretty taxing).
+ The story is ostentatiously stupid fun - like a fantastic B-movie - if you can enjoy it for what it is, and not expect something more serious like Saints Row 2.
+ Good voice acting from everyone.
+ Some fun new activities, and most of the old activities are back: Escort, Trail-blazing, Mayhem, Hostage, and more, as well as new variants (like Tank Mayhem), or new activities entirely (Guardian Angel, Assassinations).
+ Autos are still customizeable, most of the options staying the same. The vehicles drive better than than the ones in SR2, though there are fewer varieties.
+Tons of personal costume and character customizations.

+ / - Lots of R-rated content. Just saying. I mean, it is a Saints Row game. But when one of the available melee weapons is a giant d**k bat that is called the Penetrator" - yeah...

- While the activites are fun

reviewText:
The storyline is as unrealistic as it gets, within the first 10 minutes, you'll realise this. But, this is definitely not a criticism, It's a compliment. Too many games of this nature are engaging with realism and this game gives you a well needed break, and just lets you relax and have fun. To put it another way, it resembles an action movie (where everything is very unrealistic). The graphics are also a nice touch. Again, non-realistic and cartoonish. It has a nice style that I never get sick of.
The setting has now shifted from Stillwater to Steelport with the Saints now trying to assume control of new territory and the set up is all the same as before. The story carries on from the second game despite a change in location as usual rival gangs occupy the city and the STAG army are sent in to try control things. The main story missions are all well executed despite most been in bonkers territory from gunfights while skydiving right through too becoming a walking toilet (yes I kid you not).
Apart from mission games there are plenty of mini games that you can do in your own time that aren't part of the central story but will help you control more of the city which enables you to make more money to buy more weapons and upgrades and so on. What's also nice is that there are decisions to make along the way that affect the outcome of the game. You can side with an army type organisation and they'll aid you take over parts of the city or you can side with another faction and this will help you in other ways.

reviewText: TLDR at the bottom\n\nThis is one of the best and most fun open world games that I've played in a while. There's more than enough here to keep you playing for hours on end and a full 100% playthrough will take about 24 hours but with the addition of co-op, there's tons of replay value - it's also moddable. What's not to like. The side activities are a great diversion, they let you: rampage in a tank for points; blow stuff up for points; play a game show for points and more (for points.) It's the kind of stuff that you typically do in an open world game like this but this way it feels less grindy or boring to do like some other games *cough*gta4 bowling*cough* Now for the negatives - It's pretty easy to beat. I finished the main plot and a few side missions withing 12 hours on the hardest difficulty - I have the full package/goty and even then with the op" dlc weapons
date: I beat the whole thing with pistols. Also
recommended: some of the checkpointing is awful. In some sections where I get cheaply killed to say a tank appearing out of nowhere or a car exploding
hoursPlayed:
it can send you back to the very start of a 5 minute hold out or protection task

Pros:
-Lots to do
-Great fun
-Engaging side quests
-Co-op
-Mods
-Decent story - infact I liked it

reviewText:
Just first impressions:

Of all open world franchises I played like Just Cause and Grand Theft Auto I really enjoyed Saints Row: The Third the most.
I never played the two previous games but I was noted that from focusing into realism and crime simulation they just went for the comedy values, overexaggurating on purpose to mock the holywood media and stereotypes.

So far the storyline is suprisingly good, You play on a large open world buying businesses to launder money, fully customizable vehicles, ability to have a crew and companions, hilarious dialogue. What GTA And Just Cause games lack.
Except GTA had interesting storyline, Just Cause 2 storyline was complete trash, right out of the bag.

Just first impressions:

Of all open world franchises I played like Just Cause and Grand Theft Auto I really enjoyed Saints Row: The Third the most.
I never played the two previous games but I was noted that from focusing into realism and crime simulation they just went for the comedy values, overexaggurating on purpose to mock the holywood media and stereotypes.

So far the storyline is suprisingly good, You play on a large open world buying businesses to launder money, fully customizable vehicles, ability to have a crew and companions, hilarious dialogue. What GTA And Just Cause games lack.
Except GTA had interesting storyline, Just Cause 2 storyline was complete trash, right out of the bag.

reviewText: Heard allot of bad reviews for this game because its not like Saints Row 2, and granted is has way less customization and less branching story options and sidequests. That said it still has WAY more than I've ever enjoyed from Grand Theft Auto, and the story is HILLARIOUS and FUN, Customization dominates GTA, mainly since besides clothes GTA has almost none now. Also Girls can play Female Characters, I enjoyed this with my girlfriend, she loved all the jokes and oversexualization of everything. Outfits and Car Customizations look really cool, and the game is moddable. This game series destroyed GTA for me, it is just way more fun. All it needs is more Multiplayer and more Content to keep up with the previous versions as far as sidequests and story options. Even Radio Stations.

reviewText:
The storyline is as unrealistic as it gets, within the first 10 minutes, you'll realise this. But, this is definitely not a criticism, It's a compliment. Too many games of this nature are engaging with realism and this game gives you a well needed break, and just lets you relax and have fun. To put it another way, it resembles an action movie (where everything is very unrealistic). The graphics are also a nice touch. Again, non-realistic and cartoonish. It has a nice style that I never get sick of.
The setting has now shifted from Stillwater to Steelport with the Saints now trying to assume control of new territory and the set up is all the same as before. The story carries on from the second game despite a change in location as usual rival gangs occupy the city and the STAG army are sent in to try control things. The main story missions are all well executed despite most been in bonkers territory from gunfights while skydiving right through too becoming a walking toilet (yes I kid you not).
Apart from mission games there are plenty of mini games that you can do in your own time that aren't part of the central story but will help you control more of the city which enables you to make more money to buy more weapons and upgrades and so on. What's also nice is that there are decisions to make along the way that affect the outcome of the game. You can side with an army type organisation and they'll aid you take over parts of the city or you can side with another faction and this will help you in other ways.

Saints row: The third 9/10

Positives
+This game is very funny i guarantee you will get a laugh if you play this game
+THIS GAME HAS OFFLINE AND ONLINE CO-OP!!! this is fun because you can play with your friends and complete the game ez
+Free roam game. you can basically do whatever you want if you get bored of doing missions and gang operations you can just drive around kill the morningstar kill the police or act like its real life and just drive at like 2km/h and obey the speed limit. whatever tickles your fancy
+Great soundtrack. i love the songs in this game. it really suits the game
+ALSO HAS VEHICLE DELIVERY.
+has a large character customization so you make your character look ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• or like YOU.

Negatives
-has some aids mission if you do nothing youre basically dead in them
-you need a decent computer to run. if you dont there is so many explosions your computer will 100% commit suicide.
-its a third person shooter. even though this makes the game great i think they should at least add an option to put it in first person to help people who like that better
-Has a lot of bugs and glitches. One time i was in a mission and i was driving on a bridge until abrubtly outta nowhere like a RKO i feel through the thick piece of concrete supported by two giant pillars also made of concrete. plz fix

Overall this game runs smoothly most of the time if you dont go spastic with explosions other than that this is a great game that most of the time makes no sense.

9/10

reviewText:
I came into this game after having finished Saints Row 4 and 2 first, in that order. The difference between 2 and 4 is drastic, so I was interested to see where The Third would be in relation to those two. As one might assume it‚Äôs somewhere in the middle. The second game had missions with only light scripting and a big dose of unpredictable chaos at the hand of the AI and world simulation, while the fourth game was more directed and scripted with a big emphasis on comedy. It can be hard to describe just how different the two feel when actually playing. The closest thing I‚Äôve experienced in other games to the feeling of out of control madness in Saints Row 2 is in the Stalker games. The fourth might at first glance appear even crazier than the second game, but it‚Äôs a chaos that feels highly predictable and in control of the creators. The Third tries to do both things, and doesn‚Äôt do it as well as either 2 or 4 did. It is without a doubt the worst Saints Row game I‚Äôve played yet.

For the most part Saints Row The Third is perfectly fine. Visually it‚Äôs a huge improvement over the second game, and in general the level of polish is on another level. The problem though is that many of the changes make the game more conventional, and as a result a bit boring. For example the weapons and enemy types have changed quite a bit from the second game. Almost all the weapons in Saints Row 2 felt powerful, and in The Third the majority of the guns suck. They aren‚Äôt loud enough, and they don‚Äôt do enough damage which creates a frustrating bullet sponge feel, even when fighting the weakest enemies. This made many weapons unusable, like all the shotguns and all the submachine guns.

The biggest issue though I had with The Third is the story. In both 2 and 4 it was excellent! Great antagonists and a good sense of progression and character development with proper last acts that resolved everything going on in the games. Real solid work, unlike The Third where it‚Äôs more of a mess that doesn‚Äôt go anywhere. As far as games go The Third is still alright, and it has several high points, especially in the second half of the game. But it wasn‚Äôt nearly as good as the other two, and it felt unfinished. In about a third of the missions there were abrupt cuts where it seemed like there should have been a cutscene, but there was nothing. It also ended a couple hours before I expected it to. Several things are left unresolved, which added to the feeling that they were forced to cut things from the game. Everything that‚Äôs in the game is very well polished, but there are gaps, like the ending.

Because the game mechanics are more polished than the second game this feels like an easier game to recommend on one level. But on the other hand I just didn‚Äôt enjoy it as much because of that. The second game was on the surface a shoddier game, but while I was playing it there‚Äôs no question I was enjoying it more. The fourth game blows The Third out of the water in terms of story, humor, character and just about everything. Even the use of music in the fourth game is a notch above The Third. This is still a good game, but play the other two first.

reviewText:
Saints Row: The Third is a lot of fun. As the leader of the criminal gang The Saints you will steel cars, take people hostage, blow stuff up, pick fights with random passerby‚Äôs  and in general cause mayhem and destruction.

You will kill members of other gangs to gain control over their neighborhood and you will be asked to participate in rather random acts of violence. Almost every act of crime and destruction is rewarded with cash and respect. Both can be used (in different ways) to improve your characters abilities.

The smart thing about the game is that it doesn‚Äôt take itself seriously. At all. The knowing wink that states ‚Äòwe know this is just a game‚Äô and the low-brow humor could have been annoying.

The fact that you will meet the same NPC‚Äôs over and over again and that few of your actions have permanent consequences  could have been a major disappointment.

But when a game is this amoral (or even immoral), it helps that there is no illusion of a real world filled with real people.

--- --- ---

Steelport, the city where the Saints roam, seems to exist in its own reality. And of course it does. Murder, theft and all kinds of depravity don‚Äôt have real consequences. It‚Äôs difficult to mourn the death of an NPC you just shot to steel his car. You know you will meet the exact same NPC again and again.

You can destroy a large part of the town, only to discover that 10 minutes later the city has been rebuild.

You can shoot a police officer for no reason, use your in game smartphone to call one of your fellow gang members to ask for ‚Äòpolice forgiveness‚Äô and watch other police officers just walk away.

You see, normally I try to do ‚Äòthe right thing‚Äô in games. But Saints Row: The Third makes it possible to enjoy being a criminal by taking away the guilt.

But I must admit that at some point something strange happened. I started to like these characters. Early on in the game your character starts singing along with an NPC and that felt good. When near the end of the game I raced through town to save one of my friends and Bonnie Tyler started to sing ‚ÄúI Need a Hero‚Äù I felt heroic.

It helped that I made the protagonist female. Voiced by the excellent Laura Bailey (Female Voice 1) she became somebody that I liked and I could accept her violent side.

I even indulged in some character building. I made the character overweight since I figured she wouldn‚Äôt have much self-constraint. I gave her practical clothes since she is a person of action. I made her look like somebody in her mid-thirties because that made sense for a ‚Äòboss‚Äô.

And this is the sign of a good game: despite the occasional flawed gameplay and design, despite the fact that the game glorifies crime and violence, I finished the game not just for me, but also for her.

reviewText:
So, here we go.

This game... never expected anything like that from it to be honest.
Saint's Row: The Third is by far one of my favorite open world games ever. The story of the game was amazing and kept me and my friend wanting to just skip everything and go throught the story just to see what happens. This is how good the story is. Here are some of the best features of the game:

- The game never really forces you to do any missions. You can explore the world and do crazy stuff before beginning a mission.
- Lots of activities and fun things that you can do. You will play a lot before getting bored.
- Money isn't just for buying weapons and ammo. Money can be used to upgrade skills, vehicles, buy and upgrade weapons, purchase buildings to increase the cash you get per hour.
- INSANE ammount of customization. You can customize everything. EVERYTHING. From choosing how big you want your weiner to be, to even upgrading your crib.
- Creating gangs. You can make and customize your gang. You can make ninjas with shotguns roam around the city. Come on, this is ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•ing amazing.

Single-player itself is fun, but if you have one single friend YOU MUST play the Co-op. The game is even more amazing and ridiculously fun.

Just a few and minor glitches such as sometimes getting into the car you dont want or when pressing E" to enter a car
date: your character walks really slowly to the car (which might result in death
recommended: as you might be in a hurry to escape the police).\n\nDispite all these minor bugs
hoursPlayed:
this game is one of my favorite games ever.

Final Rating: FULL 10 / 10
The price tag is worth it for what you are going to get out of this game. About 16-20 hours of the main storyline and double or even triple more for exploring and doing other fun activities.
"

reviewText:
Uh
Not too sure what to write here so heres a recipe for Pancakes instead

Ingredients:
1 1/2 cups all-purpose flour
3 tablespoons sugar
1 tablespoon baking powder
1/4 teaspoon salt
1/8 teaspoon freshly ground nutmeg
2 large eggs, at room temperature
1 1/4 cups milk, at room temperature
1/2 teaspoon pure vanilla extract
3 tablespoons unsalted butter, plus more as needed

Now to make it
1. In a large bowl, whisk together the flour, sugar, baking powder, salt, and nutmeg.
2. In another bowl, beat the eggs and then whisk in the milk and vanilla.
3. Melt the butter in a large cast iron skillet or griddle over medium heat.
4. Whisk the butter into the milk mixture. Add the wet ingredients to the flour mixture, and whisk until a thick batter is just formed
5. Keeping the skillet at medium heat, ladle about 1/4 cup of the batter onto the skillet, to make a pancake. Make 1 or 2 more pancakes, taking care to keep them evenly spaced apart. Cook, until bubbles break the surface of the pancakes, and the undersides are golden brown, about 2 minutes. Flip with a spatula and cook about 1 minute more on the second side. Serve immediately or transfer to a platter and cover loosely with foil to keep warm. Repeat with the remaining batter, adding more butter to the skillet as needed.
6. Procedure for adding fruit to pancakes: Once the bubbles break the surface of the pancakes, scatter the surface with sliced or diced fruit, or chocolate chips, nuts, etc. Flip with a spatula and cook for 1 minute more, being careful not to burn toppings.

reviewText:
When I first knew of the Saints Row games, particularly this one, I just ignored it because it sounded like some GTA clone.  Gangs, driving around and doing random stuff didn't appeal to me.  Apparently, I've been missing out on all the fun.

Some things that I liked:Comedy - This game has a lot of silliness and it's aware of it.  There are some serious moments but most of the game is just so over the top that it's ridiculous (in a good way).  Most of the funny stuff were intentional, but there were some funny stuff that just happened in the course of playing the game.  For example, I was doing an escort mission, and while the clients are doing some uh... weird noises, the Hallelujah Chorus started playing on the car radio.  There were other random funny stuff that happened, but that was one of the most memorable.
Voice acting - So far, I've only used female1 voice.  I don't know if the other voices are as good.
Character customization - In addition to the standard head customization, you can also customize the body and choose the voice of your character.  I couldn't make a decent custom face if my life depended on it, but I was happy with the body customization.  You can customize your character at any time during the game.
Clothing options - This is a source of my annoyance in most games that allow you to change the clothes/armor of your character.  In this game, any piece of clothing can be worn by either male or female character.  There's no stupid normal version for male characters and ridiculous-looking version for female characters".  The clothes are normal or ridiculous
date: regardless of who's wearing them (in general
recommended: not talking about cross-dressing).  I guess the "I want more sexy" crowd and the "I want reasonable-looking clothes" crowd are both happy.\nDriving - I'm not a huge fan of driving games
hoursPlayed: but I enjoyed driving in this one.  Driving at top speed while being chased by the police or rival gangs with classical music playing on the radio was fun.\nNot really complaints
voteText: but things that I found meh:Weapon customization - There's no weapon customization.\nCheckpoint system (missions) - I like being able to save anywhere and continue exactly from where I left off.  I don't know if it was done that way (checkpoint system) because it's a console port or for some other technical reasons."

reviewText:
I played Saints Row 2, it was my first entry in the series. And after playing it, All I can say about Saints Row: The Turd is- This game sucks. I'll just list my reasons here:
-Shortest game in the whole series (Took me 9 Hours to beat, while SR4 and SR2 had 20+ hours.)
-It has writting that feels like it was written by a 12 year old (Everything is a Sex joke)
-The Character customization is ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• (The customization for clothes and appeareance feels nuttered, you no longer have Shirts, Undershirts, Coats, NO. Now you Have only TOP)
-The New gangs feel stupid, lacking any uniqueness like the ones found in Saints Row 2.
-THERE IS NO ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•ING REGGAE!!!
-The side activities have absolutely no context, you enter a side mission, and you instantly start it, no context, no reasons, no nothing.
-The cool side activites like Fight Club, Septic Avenger, and Crowd Control have been replaced with dull activities like Tank Mayhem and Proffessor Genki's Super Ethical Reality Climax.
-There are less celebrity cameos now, part of which is caused by the lack of Crowd control.
-The Saints are no longer a gang, now they have been turned into stupid celebrities who advertise energy drinks, instead of the badass gangsters they used to be.
-Also, Every Saint is less likeable than Before- Gat gets killed off  for no reason, Pierce dresses like ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•, My Fav Saint Shaundi is no longer a cute Dready pothead who loves to chill, smoke Loa dust, party, and ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•ed everyone in Stilwater, NO. Now she is a stupid hispanic looking ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• who wears tight clothes, and hates everyone and everything, FOR NO REASON.
-It has unesesary useless animations for when you're knocked down, every time you get knocked down, you have to wait for this unskippable animation of you getting up, during which you can actually get knocked back again and again.
-The Pedestrians are repetitive and boring, you no longer have Soccer Moms, Rednecks, Elderly, Richies, Bums, Patriots, Street Performers, or Gangsters. Everyone in Steelport is either a Hipster, Hooker/Stripper, Bum, or a Guido.
-There is no Multiplayer, only this stupid thing called ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•D mode.

I do not recommend this game to fans of the classics.

Its a real shame, I hear tons of Saints Row starters who say that they love the series but that this was their first game. Please, Play Saints Row 1 or 2 First, you won¬¥t be dissapointed.

reviewText: Its similar to GTA but a lot cheaper, the graphics aren't too bad, but the one thing i like is how they improved the driving mechanics this game. In saint rows II the steering was two sharp, but now its not too bad. Its very humourous, you get to smack people with a baseball bat/d1ldo. It can't get better than that. Although, it gets very repetitive and sometimes it tends to crash when you shift + tab, maybes its just me. In addition, it began crashing during the first few times i played the game, i had to do some research to solve the problem, it was a simple and easy, but time consuming problem. Overall, I really liked how the game turned out and how they gave you the option to chose what you wanted to do in certain parts of the game. If i had to rate this game out of ten, i would give it 8/10. Its not good or bad.

reviewText:
Presentation
Saints Row: The Third takes you out of Stilwater, the city where the action took place in the previous titles, and drops you into the new city of Steelport, where it is your job to take over and show everyone that the Saints are made to rule. There is little story to uncover here and even that can probably be resumed in a sentence or two, but the most important aspect of your purpose in Saints Row: The Third is that you have been put there to kick ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•, and not just anyhow, but in style. The story is only meant to introduce you to the characters and the mechanics of the game, giving you access to the tools, vehicles and weapons that you master later on in the game to use how you see fit. While the plot does give a little of background to each one of the three gangs in Steelport: The Morningstar, The Deckers and The Luchadores, most of the missions will be all about the unique ways in which they manage to entertain you, and less about the actual reason for why you just blew up an entire building. While Saints Row: The Third barely tells you anything about the community of Steelport and even the gangs themselves, it does tell you a lot about the Saints, and even if you haven't touched a Saints Row game before, it will almost instantly grow with you and transform you into a fan of the Saints just by being a part of an explosive and unscripted way of life. While some will remain with you longer than others, all characters have something of their own, from a pimp that only speaks using autotune, to a friend that makes you drive around while sitting next to a tiger, Saints Row: The Third is above all, a moshpit of craziness. To understand the logic behind this game you must not take it seriously, because it is not meant to be that at all; instead Saints Row III provides you with the same gang fighting scenery as its predecessors in a city that serves as your playground, filled with crazy characters, vehicles and missions to satisfy your thirst for endless destruction.
Rating: 7

Gameplay
If there's one thing Saints Row: The Third does well that is variety; aside from the campaign missions which will take on all sorts of crazy and explosive adventures, there are numerous other activities such as Escort, Mayhem, Snatch, Guardian Angel, Professor Genki's Super Ethical Reality Climax and many more other activities and challenges including Car Theft Missions and Assassination Contracts. Everything that you do in Saints Row: The Third will earn you cash and respect, which can be used to unlock and respectively buy upgrades and powers not only for your character, but for your crew and your strongholds as well. There is quite an impressive inventory of cars and aircrafts that you can play around with, and spending more time in Saints Row: The Third while advancing the game will only unlock more toys for you to play with, including an insane retro-game tank. This game wants to make one thing clear, and that is that the Saints are here to take over, and while the game doesn't offer a struggling story to get there, it does offer insane and pure fun in every single moment down the road, starting with a character working with a couple of Saints from a small apartment in the beginning, only to have the entire Steelport as your playground by the end of the game, leaving you free to use all the tools and weapons at your disposal in which way you best see fit. The campaign can also be played cooperatively, and aside from the missions themselves, you are free to roam around the city of Steelport with a friend, trying out new things and leaving aside any preconceived notions of multiplayer games for some good entertainment in which you will set your own objectives and goals in the heat of the moment. As fun as it is, the game doesn't come without its problems, as there are numerous glitches and sometimes mission freezes that will require you to reload the last checkpoint in order to continue, and while those appear way more often in multiplayer for some reason, you will still encounter some of those while playing alone as well.
Rating: 7.5

Graphics
While it isn't the prettiest game of its time, Saints Row: The Third does a decent job keeping up with the times, and even though it doesn't have anything that will shine out of the ordinary, the city of Steelport feels like a great playground for all the toys you'll get to try out in the game. The character models aren't the shiniest ones either, but the fact that you can customize your own character with almost almost any piece of clothing you can think of and even add tattoos makes up for it. The visual effects can feel repetitive at times, as explosions will most likely look the same no matter the objects or environment; there are also numerous weird animations that can be hard to ignore and occasional visual glitches.
Rating: 7

Audio
From electronic to rap, 80's pop hits and even classics such as Bach, Saints Row: The Third has something for everyone when it comes to its soundtrack, and thanks to its customizable playlist it is up to you to create your own tunes mix to accompany you along the road. The voice cast is quite impressive, with Troy Baker providing the default player voice, while Danielle Nicolet gets to voice Shaundi and Hulk Hogan providing the voice of Angel de la Muerte. They even had Sasha Grey from you know where voice brothel owner Viola DeWynter and Burt Reynolds voice himself in the game as Mayor Burt Reynolds. The sound effects are top notch and fit the action on screen perfectly and even when the visuals disappoint for a moment, there's always good audio to make up for it.
Rating: 10

Extras
The main campaign can be finished within 10 hours, but you can easily spend 20 more completing activities, challenges and looking for collectibles; the story itself is only an introduction to what you can expect from Saints Row: The Third, and with all the tools and weapons it has to offer the possibilities are practically endless. The entire game can also be played cooperatively which is always a great reason to jump back into the game and complete whatever you missed the first time alongside one of your buddies while trying out new things and basically having a good time.
Rating: 10

Verdict
Saints Row: The Third is above anything else an endless source of entertainment, whether you choose to play alone or with a buddy, as there is an enormous amount of activities, missions, challenges, weapons, vehicles, tools, gang fights, proprieties to buy and upgrades to unlock, ensuring that no matter what, there will always be something fun and refreshing to do in the city of Steelport as long as there will be Saints in it.
Rating Overall: 8.3

Check out the full review and a lot more about Saints Row: The Third at http://gamedragons.net/viewtopic.php?f=7&t=318

reviewText:
One of the best games I have ever played. Open world, lots of character customization, an awesome soundtrack, tons of upgrades, and enough silliness to keep things light and fun without overdoing it.
For the most part is was glitch free, there were a few times where something weird would happen, but it mostly only added to the hilarity.
All in all, highly recommended; I may not have as much time invested in this as other games, but I enjoyed playing this one way more.

Note, if you are planing to buy this game, buy The Full Package. It's $5.00 more and you get all of the DLC. I would definitely say that it's worth it, especially considering that some of the DLC's are $6.99 each.

Overall Rating: 9.8/10

reviewText:
SAINTS ROW: THE THIRD
Saints Row: The Third is GTA without context to the mayhem, cartoonish levels of violence and destruction coupled with a plot and characters that can only be described as shallow.

Rating 5/10

Thankfully Saints Row the Third is a big improvement over the terrible PC port of Saints Row 2 and the forgettable original Saints Row. It's similar in many ways to the game it wants to be, GTA, from its tired pop-culture references and over the top satire to its exaggerated violence.

It starts badly with a muddled opening couple of missions that throw you right into the action with little reasoning behind it. However after the confusing and bloated start it soon settles down into familiar open-city sandbox game play. Numerous side missions and shops are dotted around the fairly large city of Steelport with story missions available at any time. It's this freedom and sheer quantity of activities available that's the games success. From driving around with a tiger in the passenger seat to car surfing it throws a wide variety of things to do. As there is so much to do it can at times turn into a grind fest as you tick off one of the many fun but meaningless activities and challenges.

The biggest weakness then is the plot, characters and setting. The city itself is bland with forgettable locations in a non-descript North American cityscape and unlike games like GTA or Mafia each part of Steelport feels much the same as the next. The characters don‚Äôt help make it anymore interesting as even as cartoon cut-outs they are bland as they work their way through the humourless story. It feels like it's trying too hard to be a funny spoof much the same way the GTA series over-eggs its satire. Comedy shouldn't need to be forced.

There is a wide range of vehicles available, from numerous bikes, cars, planes and boats, however they all seem to handle roughly the same apart from the speed and often feel weightless as you turn on a pin in even the most worthless of vehicles or as you smash through other vehicles and the environment. Combat is much the same, waves of enemies with no weight; they are much like the blow up dolls you can find dotted around the city.

Having said all of that I still had great fun with it, more for side missions, challenges and free-roaming than for it's story but I have a feeling that's the point.

reviewText:
I will flat out admit that I had never even really heard of Saints Row before downloading this game. I wanted a game that had characters you could customize and that you could explore and play at your own pace. Saints Row: The Third was highly recommended everywhere I looked so I decided to take a chance on it.

And I am really glad that I did. I have never enjoyed a game so much. The storyline was just engaging. I did not expect it to be as crazy as it was but I have to say, I liked it. Going from jumping out of planes  to running naked and drugged through a BDSM club was more entertaining than I could have ever imagined. I found myself actually wanting to play the storyline instead of doing all the side quests first. I wanted to know what happened.

The characters themselves had great voice actors and the dialogue was spot on. It's hard not to get attached to them and actually want to protect them (even when they're being annoying little jerks and dying all the time). You can pick a voice for your character and though much of the dialogue stays the same no matter which voice you picks, each one still manages to have its own personality seperate from the others. The voice I picked, clearly had a thing for Pierce and alluded to it several times in the story. Little things like that are what make this game great.

It is a little bit laggy at times and there is one challenge at the end of the first chapter that is completely screwed up on a lot of computers due to a missing cut scene but I managed to get around that by putting my resolution on low and it worked fine. I didn't think the controls for the keyboard or mouse were particularly tricky and I'm someone with terrible hand-eye coordination so free cameras usually mess me up.

All in all, I loved it and am planning on playing it again.

reviewText:
Saints Row 3 is a game I have a lot of conflicting opinions on. There's things I like about it versus things that I absolutely despise and wish they didn't change. Though it's something that happens with every new SR game.

The combat was much improved in SR3 as was basically everything else about the gameplay. The game is really well polished and runs rather nicely with it's fancy PC port. However at the same time things were removed to reduce strain on the processor. Things like how there's no real timescale in the game, and it only shifts from day to night after doing missions/activities. Or how layered clothing was removed and replaced with more goofy customization options.

At the same time it's a game I still like to a certain extent. And one I respect Volition a whole lot for creating. Saints Row the Third is a game made by developers that took a lot of risks. Both broadening their base and shrinking it at the same time. Thankfully Volition is also creating mod tools for SR3, so hopefully my ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•ing will stop shortly thereafter.

reviewText:
Strongly recommended.

Saints Row is like a GTA but in funnier, crazier and a more arcade way.
Steal tanks in midair, surf on car, get naked and run like crazy monkey in the streets, defend yourself with a purple huge d√¨ldo, etc.

Compared to a classic GTA, Saints Row might look easier: your health regenerates (CoD like), you start with lotsa ammo and guns, once you grab a new gun it's added to your crib cache and you don't have to buy it again and so on.
However the game itself is actually much more difficult. You will have to fight both gangs and cops. The city sometimes becomes a real war zone with SWAT team rushing into an interesction full speed with their armored truck, cops choppers firing on hostiles, you defending your crib that has been attacked by a gang, the laters bringing their homies with them. Being in middle of all this mess is eerie. You won't survive with another game mechanisms. So, grab your smartphone and call your crib, your favorites homies and increase the chaos in that intersection even more. Can't seem to protect your crib? Too many people running around and shooting everywhere? Okay, call for an airstrike. Missiles will rain down that poor intersection anihilating everything.

It's a lotta fun, really. You will always find something to do in that city. There are many side missions that get unlocked when progressing into the main story. Doing those mission will increase your influence aera and spawn homies in the street that you can call in case of emergency. Also, your hourly money benefits will increase the more area you got and the more businesses and houses you buy.

And best of all, you can play the whole game in coop with a friend. How awesome is that uh?
HOW AWESOME IS THAT? While you drive, your homie is mowing down he street; while you take cover he throws nades on hostiles; while you run naked in them streets your bro is covering your tight √§ss  with a molusk launcher. Yeah you heard me. A MOLUSK LAUNCHER THAT CAN MIND CONTROL PEOPLE!!

Now you oughta get it: Saints Row is uber fun and crazy. Even the cutscenes sometimes go like: Isn't there an easier way to get into that plane?" she asks. You just raise your brows and say "Without a doubt honey.".

There are many more features this game provides

reviewText: SR3 is an irreverent shooter that focus on fun instead of reality, by ramping up the silliness to an extreme and toss reality out the window. In one of the missions, you had to fight your way out of a transport plane, which dropped things all over the sky, so you dodge stuff while you skydive, AND shoot skydivers chasing you, so you can rescue your girl (who jumped without a chute). Then when the transport tries to ram you, you shoot yourself into the cockpit (from the outside!), dive through, shoot your way through the plane AGAIN, dive out the back, and go after your girl... AGAIN. Yes, that's how silly this game is. Without the silliness, this is just a GTA style game where you get a sandbox to play in. There's a plot, and a couple major branching missions, but it's pretty silly, and it's all about playing in the costume and vehicles you want. If you like your shooters to be silly (a baseball club that's attached to a... huge ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•, for example), then SR3 is right up your alley.

~Ridiculous gameplay. Not as out-there" as SR IV

reviewText:
This should be required playing for anybody (over the age limit, at least)

This is the best game that I have ever played and it will be the most fun you have ever had. Subtle, consistent, puzzling and careful - these are what this game is not. If you want unrepentant ridiculous fun and carnage with a solid plotline this is for you, and even if you don't want that you should still play this game. The writing is some of the best I've ever come across in a game, and the dialogue easily had me cracking up while still invested in the characters - and when you finish the game and realise you've ran out of content there's always saints row 4 to pick up where you left off.

It's difficult to articulate what exactly makes this so much fun, but between how you meet your homies, playing at Genkibowl and running around the entire city naked with a baseball bat beating up cops and robbers alike it wont take you long to realise for yourself. Now go forth and take Steelport for your own.

reviewText:
I bought this for a silly lark about in what I hoped would be GTA-done-right after that series went astray, and I got it.

What I didn't expect was the surprisingly well written and acted cast and story missions with a range of likable characters, even if they're all murderous career criminals.

It's also a masterclass at giving you glimpses of something fun, then actually letting you get your hands on it shortly thereafter. For keeps. And it has tanks that---while encumbered with godawful controls---actually physically crush vehicles under them, which is glorious. And VTOLs with flappy bits. And a bit in cyberspace. And not a single NPC will phone you up and demand you take them to a dance.

reviewText:
I'm making this review many years after the game came out.
Many says that saints row it's just an apery of GTA, but i have to disagree: it's true, they are very similar but are on completely different galaxies too.
Once upon a time there was the street-gang genre, and than he splitted in half:
from the more serious, dark and violent side hatched GTA IV.
From the more irreverent, satiric and comic side, hatched SR.
With this game the developers didn't want to create another GTA, they wanted to re-create and to evolve the more silly aspects of that game.

7,5/10
